Michaelmas tearme.

div.p: AS IT HATH BEEN SVNdry times acted by the Children of Paules.
AT LONDON, ❧ Printed for A. I. and are to be sould at the signe of the white horse in Paules Churchyard. An. 1607.

div.head: Inductio.
div.stage: Enter Michaelmas Terme in a whitish Cloake, new come vp out of the countrey, a Boye bringing his Gowne after him!

sp.speaker: Micha:
sp.p: BOye?

sp.speaker: Boye:
sp.p: Here sit!

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: Lay by my conscience, giue mee my Gowne,
That weede is for the country,
We must be ciuill now, and match out Euill,
Who first made Ciuill, blacke; he pleas'd the Deuill;
So; now know I where I am, me thinkes already
I graspe best part of the Autumnian blessing
In my contentious fadome, my hand's free,
From wronger and from wronged I haue fee,
And what by sweat from the rough earth they drawe,
Is to enrich this siluer haruest, Lawe,
And so through wealthy variance, and fat brawle,
The Barne is made but Steward to the Hall;
Come they vp thicke inough?

sp.speaker: Boye:
sp.p: Oh like hops and harlots sir!

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.p: Why do'st thou couple them?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Oh very aptlye, for as the hop well boiled will make a man not stand vppon his leggs: so the harlot in time will leaue a man no leggs to stand vppon!

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: Such another and bee my heyre, I haue no Childe,
Yet haue I wealth would redeeme beggery,
I thinke it be a curse both here and forraine,
Where bags are fruitful'st, there the womb's most barren,
The poore ha's all our children, we their wealth;
Shall I be prodigall when my life cooles,
Make those my heyres whome I haue beggar'd; Fooles?
It would be wondrous; rather beggar more,
Thou shalt haue heyres enow, thou keep'st a whore,
And here comes kindred too with no meane purses,
Yet striue to be still blest with Clients curses.

div.stage: Musicke playing. Enter the other 3. Termes, the first bringing in a fellowe poore, which the other 2. aduanceth, giuing him rich Apparell, apage, and a pandar. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: What subtiltie haue we here? a fellowe
Shrugging for lifes kind benefits, shift and heate,
Crept vp in 3. Termes, wrapt in silke and siluer,
So well appointed too with Page and Pandar,
It was a happy gale that blew him hether.

list.item: 1. Thou father of the Termes haile to thee.
2. May much contention still keepe with thee.
3. Many new fooles come vp and fee thee.
2. Let e'm paye deere ynough that see thee.

lg.l: And like Asses vse such men,
When their load's off, turne e'm to graze agen.
And may our wish haue full effect, Many a suite, and much neglect.
And as it hath beene often found, Let the Clients cups come round.
Helpe your poore kinsmen when you ha got e'm. You may drinke deepe, leaue vs the bottom;
Or when there is a lambe falne in, Take you the lambe, leaue vs the skin.

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: Your dutie and regard hath mou'd vs,
Neuer till now wee thought you lou'd vs,
Take comfort from our words, and make no doubt,
You shall haue suites come sixteen times about.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We humbly thanke the patron of our hopes.

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: With what a vassaile— appetite they Gnawe,
On our reuersions; and are proud,
Coldly to tast our meates, which eight returnes
Serue in to vs as courses;
One day our writs like wilde-fowle flye abroad,
And then returne or'e Cities, Townes, and Hills,
With Clyents like dryed strawes betweene their bills;
And 'tis no few birds picke to build their Neasts,
Nor no small money that keeps Drabs and Feasts!

div.p: But Gentlemen, to spread my selfe open vnto you, in cheaper Termes I salute you, for ours haue but sixpenny fees all the yeare long, yet wee dispatch you in two howers, without demur; your Suites hang not long here after Candles be lighted: Why we call this play by such a deere and chargeable Title, Michaelmas Tearme? Knowe it consents happilye to our purpose, tho perhaps faintlie to the interpretation of many; for he that expects any great quarrels in Lawe to bee handled here, will be fondly deceaued, this onely presents those familiar accidents, which happend in Towne in the circumference of those sixe weekes, whereof Michaelmas Terme is Lord: Sat sapienti, I hope there's no fooles i'th house!
div.stage: Enter at one dore Maister Rerrage, meeting Maister Salewood.

sp.speaker: Salewood:
sp.p: What Master Rerrage?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Master Salewood? Exceedingly well met in Towne, comes your Father vp this Terme?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Why he was here three dayes before the Exchequer gapte.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Fye, such an earlie Termer?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p:
Hee's not to bee spoke withall, I dare not aske him
blessing, till the last of Nouember.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And how looks thy little venturing Coosen?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Faith like a Lute that ha's all the stringes broke, no bodie will meddle with her.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Fye, there are Doctors enow in Towne will string her againe, and make her sound as sweete as ere shee did, is shee not married yet?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Sh' as no lucke, some may better steale a horse than others looke on. I haue knowen a virgin of fiue bastardes wedded, faith when all's donne we must bee faine to marrie her into the North I'me affrayd.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: But will shee passe so thinke you?

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Puh, any thinge that is warme ynough is good ynough for them; so it come in the likenes, tho the Deuill be in't, the'ile venture the fiering.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: They're worthy spirits yfaith, heard you the Newes?

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Mistris Difficult is falne a widdowe.

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Say true, is Master Difficult the Lawyer dead?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Easilie dead sir.

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Pray when died hee?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: What a question's that? when should a Lawyer dye but in the vacation, hee ha's no leisure to die in the Tearme-time, beside the Noyse there would fetch him againe.

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Knew you the nature of his disease.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Faith some say he dyed of an old griefe he had, that the vacation was foureteene weekes long.

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: And very likely. I knew 'twould kill him at last, t'as troubled him a long time, hee was one of those that would faine haue brought in the heresie of a fift Tearme, often crying with a loud voice, oh why should we loose Bartholmew weeke?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: He sauours, stop your Nose, no more of him.

div.stage: Enter master Cockstone, a Gentleman meeting master Easye of Essex.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Yong maister Easye, let me salute you sir, when came you?

sp.speaker: Easye:
sp.p: I haue but Inn'd my horse since master Cockstone.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.l: You seldome visit London master Easye,
But now your Fathers dead tis your onely course,
Here's gallants of all sizes, of all lasts,
Here you may fit your foote, make choyse of those
Whome your affection may reioyce in:

sp.speaker: Easye:
sp.l: You haue easily possest me I am free,
Let those liue hindes that know not libertie.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Master Rerrage?

sp.speaker: Eas:
sp.p: Good master Salewood, I am proud of your society.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: What gentleman might that bee?

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.l: One master Esay, h'as good land in Essex,
a faire free-brested Gentleman, somewhat too open,
bad in man, worse in woman,
the Gentrye-fault at first, he is yet fresh
and wants the Citie powdring, but what newes?
I'st yet a match twixt master Qomodoes the rich Drapers
daughter and your selfe.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Faith sir, I am vildly riuald!

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Vildly? by whome.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: One Andrewe Lethe crept to a little warmth, and now so proud that he forgets all stormes, one that nere wore apparell, but like ditches 'twas cast before hee had it, now shines bright in rich embroderies, him master Quomodo affects, the daughter him, the mother onely mee, I rest most doubtfull, my side being wookest.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Yet the mothers side being surer than the Fathers, it may proue, men pleade for money best, women for loue.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Slid master Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: How then, affraid of a woollen draper.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: He warn'd mee his house, and I hate hee should see me abroad!

div.stage: Quomodo with his two spirits, Shortyard and Falselight.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Oh my 2. spirits Shortyard and Falselight, you that haue so enricht me, I haue industrie for you both?

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Then doe you please vs best sir.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Wealthy employment.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: You make me icth sir.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: You Falselight as I haue directed you.

sp.speaker: Fals:
sp.p: I am nimble.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Goe, make my course commodities, looke, seeke, with subtile art beguile the honest eye, be neere to my trapwindowe, cunning Falselight.

sp.speaker: Fals:
sp.p: I neuer failde it yet.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.l: I know thou didst not;
But now to thee my true and secret Shortyard,
Whome I dare trust ee'n with my wife,
Thou nere didst mistris harme, but master, good,
There are too few of thy name Gentlemen,
And that we feele, but Citizens abundance,
I haue a taske for thee my pregnant spirit,
To exercise thy poynted wits vppon.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Giue it me, for I thirst.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.l: Thine care shall drinke it,
Know then I haue not spent this long Vacation
Onely for pleasures sake, giue me the man
Who out of recreation culls aduantage,
Diues into seasons, neuer walkes, but thinkes,
Nerides, but plots, my iourney was toward Essex.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Most true?

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Where I haue seene what I desire.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: A woman?

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Puh; a woman, yet beneath her, that which shee often treades on. Yet commands her land, fayre neate Land.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: What is the marke you shoote at.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Why the fayrest to cleaue the heire in twayne, I meane his Title to murder his estate, stifle his right in some some detested prison, there are means and waies enow to hooke in Gentry, besides our deadlye enmitye which thus stands they'r busye 'bout our wiues, We 'bout their Lands.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.l: Your reuenge is more glorious,
To be a cuckold is but for one life,
When land remaines to you, your heire, or wife!

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Ah sirrah, doe we stinge'm, this fresh gallant rode newly vp before me!

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: I beseech his name.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Yong master Easye.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Easye? It may fall right.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: I haue enquir'd his haunt, stay, ha, I that, 'tis, that's he, thats he!

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Happilie!

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Obserue, take surely note of him, hee's fresh and free shift thy selfe speedily into the shape of gallantrye, Ile swell thy purse with angels, keepe foote by foote with him, out-dare his expences, flatter, dice, and brothell to him, giue him a sweete tast of Sensuality, traine him to euery wastfull sin, that he may quickly neede health, but especially money, rauish him with a dame or twoo, bee his bawde for once, Ile bee thine for euer, drinke drunke with him, creepe into bed to him, kisse him and vndoo him, my sweete spirit.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Let your care dwell in me soone shall it shine, What subtiltie is in man, that is not mine.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: O my most cherefull spirit, goe, dispatch, Gentrye is the cheife fish we Tradesmen catch.

sp.speaker: Easye:
sp.p: What's here?

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Oh, they are bils for Chambers.

sp.speaker: Eas:
sp.p: Against Saint Andrewes, at a Painters house, ther's a faire chamber ready furnisht to bee let, the house not onely endowed with a newe fashion forepart, but which is more conuenient for a Gentleman, with a very prouident backe-doore.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Why here's vertue still; I like that thing that's necessary, as well as pleasant.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: What newes in yonder paper.

sp.speaker: Rerra:
sp.p: Ha? seeke you for newes, there's for you!

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Whose tis? in the name of the blacke Angels, Andro Gruill.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: No, Andro Lethe!

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Lethe?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Has forgot his fathers name, poore Walter Gruill that begot him, fed him, and brought him vp.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Not hither.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: No; 'twas from his thoughts, hee brought him vp belowe.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: But do's he passe for Lethe.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Mongst strange eyes that no more knowe him, then he knowes himselfe, thats nothing now, for master Andro Lethe, a gentleman of most receiued parts, forgetfulnes, Lust, Impudence, and Falshood, and one especiall Courtly quality; to wit, no wit at all, I am his Riuall for Quomodoes daughter, but hee knowes it not.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Has spyed vs ore his paper.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Oh thats a warning to make our duties ready.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Salute him, hang him.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Puh, wish his health a while, heele be laide shortly, let him gorge Venison for a time, our doctors will bring him to dry mutton; seeme respectiue to make his pride swell like a Toade with dewe.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Master Lethe!

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Sweete master Lethe.

sp.speaker: Lathe:
sp.p: Gentlemen your pardon, I remember you not.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Why we supt with you last night sir!

sp.speaker: Lethe:
sp.l: Oh cry you mercy, 'tis so long agoe,
I had quite forgot you, I must be forgiuen,
Acquaintaince, deere societie, suites and things,
Do so flowe to mee; that had I not the better memorie!
Twould be a wonder I should know my selfe,
Esteeme is made of such a dizzy mettall;
I haue receiu'd of many gifts ore night
Whome I haue forgot ere morning, meeting the men,
I wisht em to remember me agen,
They doo so: then if I forget agen,
I know what helpt before, that will helpe then,
This is my course, for memorie I haue been told
Twentie preserues, the best I find is gold;
Ey truely! are you not knights yet, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Not yet!

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: No, that must bee lookt into, tis your owne sault,
I haue some store of Venison, where shall we deuoure it,
Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.l: The horne were a fit place.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: For Venison, fit,
The horne hauing chast it,
At the horne— weele Rime to that.—

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Tast it.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Wast it.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Cast it.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: Thats the true rime indeed, wee hunt our Venison
twice I tell you, first out a'th parke, next out a'th Bellie.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.l: First dogs take paines to make it fit for men,
Then men take payne to make it fit for dogs.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.l: Why this is kindnes, a kind Gallant, you,
And loue to giue the dogs more than their due,
We shall attend you sir.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: I pray doo so.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: The horne.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Easily remembred that you know!

div.p:
But now vnto my present busines, the Daughter yeildes, and Quomodo consents, onely my mistris Quomodo, her mother without regard runs full against mee, and sticks hard! Is there no law for a woman that will run vpon a man at her owne apperill. Why should not shee consent, knowing my state, my sudaine fortunes, I can command a custerd, and other bakemeats, death of sturgeon, I could keepe house with nothing, what friends haue I? how well am I beloued, ee'n quite throughout the scullery, not consent? tis ee'n as I haue writ, Ile be hang'd, and shee loue mee not herselfe & wold rather preserue me, as a priuate friend to her own pleasures, than any way aduance her daughter vpon me to beguile herselfe, then how haue I relieued her in that poynt, let me peruse this letter. Good mistris Quomodo, or rather as I hope ere the Terme end, mother Quomodo, since only your consent keeps a loofe off and hinders the copulation of your daughter, what may I thinke, but that it is a meere affection in you, doating vppon some small inferiour vertue of mine, to draw me in vpon your self, if the case stand so, I haue comfort for you: for this you may well assure your selfe, that by the marriage of your daughter I haue the better meanes and opportunity to your selfe, and without the least suspition. This is moouing stuffe, and that workes best with a Citizens wife, but who shall I get to conuey this now: my Page I ha sent forth, my Pandar I haue imployd about the country, to looke out some third sister, or entice some discontented Gentlewoman from her husband, whome the laying out of my appetite shall maintaine, nay Ile deale like an honourable Gentleman, Ile bee kinde to women, that which I gather i'th day, Ile put into their purses at night, you shall haue no cause to raile at me, no faith, Ile keepe you in good fashion Ladyes, no meaner men then knights shall ransome home your gownes, and recouer your smocks, Ile not dallye with you— some poore widdow woman would come as a necessary bawd now: and see where fitly comes— my mother! curse off
pouerty do's shee come vp to shame me, to betray my birth, and cast soyle vpon my new Suite, let her passe me, Ile take no notice of her, Scuruye— murrey— Carsey!

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: By your leaue and like your worship.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Then I must proudly venture it; to me good woman.

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: I beseech one word with your worship.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Prethe be breife then.

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: Pray can your worship tell me any tydings of one Andro Gruill, a poore sonne of mine owne.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: I know a gallant Gentleman of the name, one master Andro Gruill and well receiude amongst Ladyes.

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: That not he then!
Hee is no Gentleman that I meane.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Good woman if he be a Gruill, hee's a Gentleman i'th mornings: thats a Gentleman a'th first, you canot tel me

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: No truely, his father was an honest vpright Tooth-drawer.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: O my teeth.

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: An't please your worship, I haue made a fore iourney out, all this vacant time, to come vp and see my sonne Andro, poore Walter Gruill his Father has layd his life, and left mee alone woman, I haue not one husband in all the world, therefore my comming vp is for reliefe an't like your worship, hoping that my sonne Andro is in some place about the Kitchin.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Kitchin, puh, fah.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Or a seruingman to some Kinght of worship.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Oh let mee not indure her! Knowe you not mee good woman?

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Alasse, an't please your worship, I neuer sawe such a glorious suite since the hower I was kersend.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: Good, shee knowes me not, my glory do's disquite mee,
Beside my poorer name being drencht in Lethe,
Sheele hardly vnderstand me, what a fresh ayre can doo!
I may employ her as a priuate drudge,
To passe my letters and secure my lust,
And nere be noted mine, to shame my blood,
And drop my stayning birth vppon my raiment, faith good
woman you will hardly get to the speech of master Andro,
I tell you.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: No?
Marry hang him, and like your Worship, I haue knowen the day when no body carde to speake to him!

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: You must take heed how you speak ill of him now I cantell you; hee's so employde.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Imployde for what?

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: For his behauiour, wisdome, and other vertues.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: His vertues? no tis well knowen, his father was too poore a man to bring him vp to any vertues; hee can scarce write and reade.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Hee's the better regarded for that amongst Courtiers, for thats but a needy qualitie!

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: If it be so, then heele be great shortly, for he has no good parts about him.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Well good woman, or mother, or what you will.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Alack the day, I know your worship scornes to cal me mother: tis not a thing fit for your worship indeede, such a simple old woman as I am.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: In pitty of thy long iourney, there's six-pence British: tend vpon me, I haue busines for you.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Ile waite vpon your Worship.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Two pole off at least.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: I am a cleane ould woman, an't like your Worship.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: It goes not by cleannes here good woman, if you were fowler, so you were brauer, you might come neerer.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Nay and that be the fashion, I hope I shall (Exit .get it shortly, there's no woman so ould but she may learne; and as an old Lady delights in a young Page or monckey, so there are young Courtiers will be hungry vpon an old woman, I warrant you.

div.stage: Enter Lethes Pandar with a Country wench.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Come, leaue your puling and sighing.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: Beshrew you now, why did you entice me from my father

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p:
Why? to thy better aduancement, wouldst thou a pretty
beautifull— Iuicy squall, liue in a poore thrumbd house i'th cuntry in such seruile— habiliments, and may well passe for a gentlewoman i'th Citie, do's not 5 hundred do so thinkst thou, and with worse faces, oh, now in these latter dayes, the Deuill raygning tis an age for clouen creatures? but why sad now? yet indeed tis the fashion of any Curtizan to be sea-sicke i'th first Voyage, but at next shee proclaimes open wars, like a beaten souldier: why Northampton-shire Lasse do'st dreame of virginity now? remember a loose-bodied Gowne wench, & let it goe, wires, & tyres, bents and bums, felts and falls, thou that shalt deceiue the world, that Gentlewomen indeed shall not be knowen from others; I haue a master to whome I must prefer thee, after the aforesayd decking, Lethe by name, a man of one most admired property, he can both loue thee and for thy better aduancement be thy Pandar himselfe, an exlent sparke of humility.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: Well heauen forgiue you, you traine me vp too't.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Why I doe acknowledge it, and I thinke I doe you a pleasure in't.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: And if I should proue a harlot now, I should be bound to curse you.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Bound? nay and you proue a harlot, youle be loose ynough.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: If I had not a desire to goe like a gentlewoman, you should be hangd, ere you should get me too't I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Nay thats certain, nor a 1000. more of you, I know, you are all chast ynough, till one thing or other tempt you! deny a Sattin gowne and you dare now?

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: You knowe I haue no power to doo't, and that makes you so wilfull: for what woman is there such a beast that will deny any thing that is good.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: True they will not, most dissembler.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: No, and shee beare a braue mind shee will not I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.l: Why, therfore take heart, faint not at all,
Women nere rise, but when they fall,
Let a man breake, hee's gone, blowen vp,
A womans breaking sets her vp,
Virginitie is no Citie— Trade,
You're out a'th Freedome, when you're a mayde,
Downe with the lattis tis but thin,
Let courser beauties worke within:
Whome the light mocks, thou art faire and fresh,
The guilded flies, will light vpon thy flesh.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.l: Beshrew your sweet enchantments, you have wun.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.l: How easily soft women are vndone:
So farewell holesome weeds where treasure pants,
And welcome silkes, where lyes disease and wants:
Come wench, now flow thy Fortunes in to blesse thee,
Ile bring thee where thou shalt be taught to dresse thee!

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: Oh as soone as may be, I am in a swone till I bee a gentlewoman, and you know what flesh is mans meate, tell it be drest.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Most certain, no more a woman.

div.head: Actus Secundus.
div.stage: Enter Rerrage, Salewood, Lethe, Easye, with Shortyard alias Blastfield, at dice.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Gentlemen I ha sworne Ile change the roome: dice?

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: You see I'me patient gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: I, the feinds in't, you're patient, you put vp all. Deuils.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Come set me gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: An Essex gentleman sir.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: An vnfortunate one sir.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Eas:
sp.p: Hees second to my bosome.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Ile giue you that comfort then sir, you must not want money as long as you are in towne sir.

sp.speaker: Eas:
sp.p: No sir?

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: I am bound in my loue to him to see you furnisht, and in that comfort I recouer my salute agen sir.

sp.speaker: Eas:
sp.p: Then I desire to be more deere vnto you.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: I rather study to be deare vnto you— boy, fill some wine.— I knew not what faire impressier I receiud, at first, but I began to affect your societie very speedily.

sp.speaker: Eas:
sp.p: I count my selfe the happier.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: To master Alsup sir, to whose remembrance, I could loue to drinke till I were past remembrance.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I shall keepe Christmasse with him sit, where your health shall likewise vndoubtedly be remembred, and therevpon I pledge you:— I would sue for your name sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Your suite shall end in one Tearme sir: my name is Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Kind maister Blastfield, your deerer acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Nay come, will ye draw in Gentlemen? set me:

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Faith I'me scatterd.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Sir, you shall not giue out so meanely of your selfe in my companie for a Million: make Such priuie to your disgrace? you'r a Gentleman of faire fortunes; keep me your reputation; set 'em all, there's crownes fo you.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Sir you binde me infinitely in these courtesies.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: You must alwayes haue a care of your Reputation here in Town maister Easie, altho you ride downe with nothing, it skils not.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I'me glad you tell me that yet, then I'me indifferent. Well, come: who throwes? I set all these.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why, well said.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: This same maister Lethe here begins to vndo vs agen.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Ah sir, I came not hither but to win.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And then you'le leaue vs, thats your fashion.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Hee's base that visits not his friends:

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: But hee's more base that carries out his winnings.
None will doe so but those haue base beginnings

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: It is a thing in vse and euer was, I passe this time.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I wonder you should passe. And that you're sufferd.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.l: Tut, the Dice are ours,
Then wonder not at those that haue most powrs.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: The Diuell and his Angels.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Are these they? Welcome deere Angels, where y'are curst nere stay.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Heere's lucke.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Lets search him Gentlemen, I think he wears a smock:

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I knew the time, he wore not halfe a shirt, iust like a Pee.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: No, how did he for the Rest?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Faith he compounded with a couple of Napkins at Barnet, and so truss vp the lower parts.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Twas a prettie shift yfaith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: But maister Lethe ha's forgot that too.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: A mischiefe on't to loose all: I could—

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Nay but good Ma Easie, do not do your self that tirannie I beseech you, I must not ha you alter your body now for the Purge of a little money: you vndoe me and you doe.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Twas al I brought vp with me, I protest master Blastfield, all my rent till next quarter.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Pox of money, talke not on't I beseech you, what said I to you? Masse I am out of cash my selfe too,— Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Anon sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Run presently to master Gum the Mercer, and wil him to tell out two or three hundred pound for mee, or more according as he is furnisht: Ile visit him ith morning say.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It shall be said sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Doe you heare boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: If master Gum bee not sufficiently readie, call vppon master Profit the Goldsmith.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It shall be done sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I know I was not sent yet now is the time.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Let them both rest till another occasion: you shall not need to run so farre at this time, take one nier hand go to Ma. Quomodo the Draper, and will him to furnish mee instantly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Now I goe sir.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: It seemes y'are wel knowne master Blastfield, and your credite verie spacious here ith Citie.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p:
Master Easie, let a man beare himselfe portly, the whorsons will creepe to him a'th their bellies, and their wiues a'th their backs: ther's a kinde of bolde grace expected throughout all the parts of a Gentleman: then for your obseruances, a man must not so much as spit but within line and fashion. I tell you what I ha done: somtimes I carrie my water all London ouer, onely to deliuer it proudly at the Standard, and do I passe altogether vnnoted thinke you? No, a man can no sooner peep out his head, but ther's a bow bent at him out of
some watch tower, or other.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: So readily sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Push, you know a bowe's quickely readie, tho a Gun belong a charging, and will shoote fiue times to his once, Come, you shall beare your selfe Iouially: take heede of setting your lookes to your losses, but rather smile vppon your ill lucke, and inuite 'em to morrow to another breakefast of Bones.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Nay ile forsweare dicing.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What? peace? I am ashamed to heare you: will you ceasse in the first losse, shewe mee one Gentleman that ere did it? Fie vppon't I must vse you to companie I perceyue, youde be spoilde else: forsweare Dice? I would your friends heard you yfaith.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Nay I was but in iest sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I hope so, what woulde Gentlemen say of you? there goes a Gull that keepes his money, I would not haue such a report goe on you, for the Worlde as long as you are in my companie. Why man fortune alters in a Minute, I ha knowne those haue recouered so much in an houre, their purses were neuer sicke after.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Oh worse then consumption of the Liuer! consumption of the patrimonie.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How now? marke their humours master Easie.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Forgiue me, my posteritie, yet vngotten.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Thats a penitent Maudlen Dicer.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Few knowe the sweets that the plaine life allowes. Vilde sonne that surfets of his fathers browes.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Laugh at him master Easie.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Ha, ha ha.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Ile bee damn'd and these bee not the bones of some queane that couzened me in her life, and now consumes mee after her death.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Thats the true-wicked-blasphemous, and soul-shuddering Dicer, that will curse you all seruice time, & attribute his ill lucke alwayes to one Drab or other.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Dick, Hell-gill: the hapie Newes.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I haue her for you sir.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Peace, what is she?

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Yong, beautifull and plump.— a delicate peece of sin.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Of what parentage?

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Oh a Gentlewoman of a great house.

sp.speaker: Leh.
sp.p: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Shee newly came out of a Barne; yet too good for a Tooth-drawers sonne.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Is she wife or maide?

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: That which is dantiest, Maide

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Ide rather shee'd beene a wife.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: A wife sir, why?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Oh Adulterie is a great deale sweeter in my minde.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Diseases gnaw thy bones. I thinke she has deserud to be a wife sir.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: That will moue well.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Her firstlinge shall be mine. Swine looke but for the huskes, the meate be thine.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: How now Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Maister Quomodo takes your worships greeting exceeding kindely, and in his commendations returnes this answere, that your worship shall not be so apt to receiue it, as hee willing to lend it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why, we thanke him yfaith.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Troth, and you ha reason to thanke him sir, t'was a verie friendly answere.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Push, a Gentleman that keeps his daies euen here ith City (as I my selfe watch to doe) shall haue many of those answeres in a tweluemonth, maister Easie.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I promise you sir I admire your carriage, and begin to hold a mor reu'rend respect of you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Not so I beseech you, I giue my friends leaue to bee inward with me,— will you walke Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Wee're for you. Present her with this Iewell my first token.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: There are certaine Country-men without enquiring for maister Rerage, and maister Salewood.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Tennants!

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.p: Thou reuiu'st vs Rascall.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: When's our next meeting Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Shor.
sp.p: To morrow night, This Gentleman, by me inuites you all, Do you not Maister Easie?

sp.speaker: Easie.
sp.p: Freely sir.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.p: We doe imbrace your loue— a pure fresh Gull

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Thus make you men at parting duetifull, And rest beholding to you, tis the slight To be remembred, when you'r out of sight.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: A prettie vertue.

div.stage: Enter the Countrie-Wenches Father, that was entisc'd for Leth:

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Where shall I seeke her now?— oh if she knew The Dangers that attend on womens liues, She would rather lodge vnder a poore thatcht Roofe Then vnder carued seelings: she was my ioy, And all content that I receiu'd from life, My deere and onely Daughter: What saies the Note she left, let mee agen With stayeder greefe peruse it— Father? wonder not at my so suddaine departure, without your leaue or knowledge, thus vnder pardon I excuse it, had you had knowledge of it, I know you would haue sought to restraine it, and hinder me from what I haue long desirde, being now happilye preferr'd to a Gentlemans seruice in London; about Holborne, if you please to send, you may heare well of me—
sp.l: As false as she is disobedient,
iu'e made larger inquirie, left no place
(Where Gentrie keepes) vnsought, yet cannot heare,
Which driues me moste into a shamefull feare:
Woe worth th' infected cause that makes me visit
This man-deuouring Cittie— where I spent
My vnshapen youth, to be my ages cursse,
And surfetted away my name and state,
In swinish Riots, that now being sober,
I doe awake, a Begger,— I may hate her.
Whose youth voides wine, his age is curst with water,
Oh heauens! I know the price of ill, too well,
What, the confusions are in whome they dwell,
And how soone Maides are to their Ruins won
One minute, and aeternally vndone:
So in mine may it: may it not be thus?—
Though she be poore, her honours preceous,
May be my present forme, and her fond feare,
May chace her from me, if her eye should get me,
And therefore as my loue and wants aduise.
Ile serue vntill I finde her in disguise.
Such is my care to fright her from base euils
I leaue calme state to liue amongst you, deuils.

div.stage: Lethes Mother enters with Quomodoes wife with the Letter.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Were these fit wordes thinke you to be sent to anye Cittizens wife, to enioy the Daughter, and loue the mother too for a neede? I would foulye scorne that man, that should loue me onely for a neede I tell you: and heere the Knaue writes agen, that by the mariage of my Daughter, a has the better meanes and opportunitie to my selfe, hee lies in his Throate like a villaine, he has no opportunitie of mee, for all that, tis for his betters to haue opportunitie of me, and that he shall well knowe— a base proud knaue— a has forgot how he came vp, & brought two of his countrie men to giue their words to my husband for a sute of greene Karsey, a has forgot all this, and how does hee appeare to me, when his white Sattin suttes on, but like a Magot crept out of a Nut-shell, a faire bodie and a foule necke, those partes that are couered of him, lookes indifferent well, because we cannot see e'm else for all his clensing, pruning and paring, hee's not worthy a Brokers Daughter, and so tell him.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: I will indeede forsooth.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: And as for my Childe, I hope sheele bee ruld in Time, though she be folish yet & not be carryed away with a cast of Manchets, a Bottle of wine, or a Custard, and so I pray certifie him.

sp.speaker: Grui.
sp.p: He doe your errant effectually.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Art thou his Ant— or his—

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Alasse— I am a poore drudge of his.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Faith and thou wert his Mother, he would make thee his drudge I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Marrie out vppon him, sir reuerence of your mistris-ship

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Heer's somewhat for thy paines, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Tis more then he gaue me since I came to him.

div.stage: Enter Quomodo and his Daughter Su.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How now, what prating haue we heare? whispers, dumshowes? why Tomazin, goo too— my shop is not altogether so darke as some of my neighbours, where a man may be made Cuckold at one ende, while hee's measuring with his yard at tother.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Onely commendations sent from Maister Lethe your worshipfull Sonne in law that should be.

sp.speaker: Quo
sp.p: Oh, & that you like not he that can make vs rich in custom, strong in friends, happy in suites, bring vs into all the romes a sundaies, from the leads to the seller, pop vs in with Venison til wee cracke agen, & send home the rest in an honorable Napkin— this man you like not forsooth?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: But I like him father.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: My blessing goe with thy liking

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: A number of our Cittizens hold our credit by't to come home drunk, and say wee ha beene at Court: then how much more credit i'st to be drunke there indeede?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Tut, thy Mothers a foole— pray what's Maister Rerage whom you pleade for so?

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Why, first he is a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I, hee's often first a Gentleman that's last a begger.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: My father tels you true, what should I do with a gentleman, I knowe not which way to lye with him.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Tis true too— thou knowst beside, we vndoe Gentlemen dayly

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: That makes so few of e'm marrie with our Daughters, vnles it be one green foote or other: next, M. Rerage has land & liuing, tother but his walke i'th street, & his snatching dyet, hee's able to entertaine you in a faire house of his owne, tother in some nooke or corner, or place vs behind the cloath like a company of Puppets: at his house you shall bee seru'd curiously, sit downe & eate your meate with leasure, there we must be glad to take it standing, & without either salt, cloath, or trencher, and say we are befriended too.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Oh, that giues a Citizen a better appetite then his Garden.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: So say I Father, me thinkes it does me most good when I take it standing, I know not how all womens mindes are:

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Faith I thinke they are al of thy minde for that thing, how now Falslight?

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: I haue descri'd my fellow Short-yard, alias Blastfield, at hand with the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Oh my sweete Short-yard!— Daughter, get you vp to your Virginalls: by your leaue Mistris Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why I hope I may sit ith shop, may I not?

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: That you may, and welcome sweete hony-thye, but not at this season, there's a Buck to be strucke.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Well, since i'me so expresly forbidden, ile watch aboue ith gallerie, but ile see your knauerie.

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: Be you preparde as I tell you.

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: You neare feard me:

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: Oh that sweete, neate, comely, proper, delicate parcell of land, like a fine Gentlewoman ith waste: not so great as prettie, prettie: the Trees in Summer whistling, the siluer waters by the Bankes harmoniouslye gliding, I should haue beene a Scholler, an excellent place for a student: fit for my Sonne that lately commenc'd at Cambridge, whom now I haue plac'd at Innes of Court: Thus wee that sildome get Landes honestly, must leaue our heires to inherit our knauerie: but whist, one turne about my shoppe and meete with e'm.

div.stage: Enter Maister Easie, with Short-yard, alias Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: Is this it sir?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I, let me see, this is it: signe of three Knaues, tis it!

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: Doe you heare sir, what lacke you Gentlemen? see good Kersies or broad cloathes heere, I pray come neere— Maister Blastfield?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I thought you would know me anon.

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p:
You'r exceeding welcome to Towne sir, your worship must pardon me, tis alwaies mistie weather in our shops heere: we are a Nation the Sunne here shines vpon,— Came
this Gentleman with you?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: O salute him fairely, hee's a kinde Gentleman, a verie in ward of mine.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Then I crye you mercy sir, y'are especially welcome.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: I returne you thankes sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: But how shall I doe for you now Maister Blastfield?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Why whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: It is my greatest affliction at this instant, I am not able to furnish you.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: How maister Quomodo, pray say not so, sl'ud you vndoe me then.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Vpon my Religion Maister Blastfield, bonds lye forfeete in my hands, I expect the receite of a thousand euerie houre, and cannot yet set eye of a penny.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: That's strange me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Tis mine owne pittie that plots against me Maister Blastfield, they knowe I haue no conscience to take the for feture, and that makes em so bould with my mercie.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: I am sorry for this.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Neuer the lesse, if I might intreate your delay but the age of three daies to expresse my sorrow now, I would double the summe, and supply you with foure or fiue hundred.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Let me see,— three daies.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I good sir, and it may be possible.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: Doe you heare Maister Blastfield,

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: You knowe i'ue alreadie enuited all the Gallants to sup with me to night.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: That's true yfaith.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: Twill be my euerlasting shame, if I haue no monye to maintaine my bountie.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I nere thought vpon that— I look't still when that should come from him, wee haue strickly examined our expences, it must not be three daies Maister Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: No then i'me afraide twill be my griefe sir.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: Maister Blastfield, ile tell you what you may doe now.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What good sweete bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Send to Master Goome, or Master Profit, the Mercer and Goldsmith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Masse that was well remembred of thee— I perceyue the Trout will bee a little troublesome ere hee bee catcht— Boy. Boy. Here sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Runne to Master Goome, or Master Profite, and carrie my present occasion of money to em.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I runne sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Me thinks Maister Blastfield, you might easily attaine to the satisfaction of 3. dayes, heer's a Gentleman your friend I dare say will see you sufficiently possest till then.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Not I sir, by no meanes: master Blastfield knowes I'me further in want then himselfe, my hope rests all vpon him, it stands vpon the losse of my credit to Night, if I walke without money.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why maister Quomodo, what a fruitlesse Motion haue you put forth, you might well assure your selfe this gentleman had it not if I wanted it: why our purses are brothers we desire but equall fortunes: in a word w'are man and wife, they can but lie together, and so doe we.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: As nere as can be yfaith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And to say truth, tis more for the continuing of this Gentlemans credit in Towne then any incitement from mine owne want only, that I couet to be so immediatly furnishd— you shall heare him confesse as much himselfe.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Tis most certaine master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Oh here comes the Boy now: How now Boy, what sayes maister Goome, or master Profit?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, thei'r both walke foorth this frostie morning to Brainford, to see a Nurse-childe.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A Bastard be it, spite and shame.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Nay, neuer vex your selfe sweet master Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Bewitcht I thinke.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Doe you heare sir? you can perswade with him.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: A little sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p:
Rather then he should be altogither destitute, or be
too much a vexation to himselfe, he shall take vp a commoditie of cloath of me tell him.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Why la! by my troth t' was kindly spoken.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Two hundred pounds worth vpon my Religion say.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: So disastrously.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Nay, maister Blastfield, you doe not heare what master Quomodo said since, like an honest true Citizen yfaith: rather then you should grow diseasde vpon't, you shall take vp a commoditie of two hundred pounds worth of cloath.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: The mealie Moth consume it, would hee hame turne Pedler now? what should I doe with cloath?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Hee's a verie wilfull Gentleman at this Time yfaith: he knowes as well what to doe with it, as I my selfe Iwis: ther's no Merchant in Town but will be greedy vpon't, and pay downe mony vpo'th naile, the'l dispatch it ouer to Middle-borrow presently, and raise double commoditie by exchange, if not, you know tis Tearme-time, and Michaelmas Tearm too, the Drapers haruest, for footcloaths, riding suts, walking suits, chamber gownes, and hall gownes.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Nay, Ile say that, it comes in as fit a time as can be.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Nay take me with you agen ere you go sir, I offer him no trash tell him, but present mony, say, where I know some Gentlemen in towne ha beene glad, and are glad at this time, to take vp commodities in Hawks hoods, and browne paper.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Oh horrible, are there such fooles in towne?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I offer him no trash tell him, vpon my Religion you may say,— Now my sweet Shortyard,— now the hungry fish begins to nibble: one end of the worme is in his mouth yfaith.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Why stand I here (as late our gracelesse Dames
That found no eyes) to see that Gentleman
Aliue in state and credit executed
Helpe to rip vp himselfe do's all he can,
Why am I wife to him that is no man?
I suffer in that Gentlemans confusion.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Nay be perswaded in that master Blastfield tis readie money at, the Marchants beside, the Winterseason and all falls in as pat as can be to helpe it.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Well Maister Easie, none but you could haue perswaded me to that, come, would you would dispatch then Maister Quomodo, where's this cloath?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Full and whole within, all of this peece of my Religion Maister Blastfield, feel't, nay feel't and spare not, Gentlemen! your fingers and your iudgement.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Clothe's good.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: By my troth exceeding good cloath, a good wale t'as,

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Falslight.

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: I'me neere out 'athe shop sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Go, call in a Porter presently to carrie away the cloath with the Starre marke, whither will you please to haue it carryed Maister Blastfield?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Faith to Maister Beggar-land, hee's the onely Marchant now: or his Brother Maister Stilliard-downe, there's little difference.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Y'aue hapned vpon the money men sir, they and some of their Bretheren I can tell you, will not sticke to offer thirtie thousand pound to be curst still, great monyed men, their stockes lye in the Poores throates: but youle see me sufficiently discharg'd Maister Blastfield ere you depart.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: You haue alwaies found me righteous in that.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Falslight.

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: You may bring a Scriuener along with you.

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: Ile remember that sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Haue you sent for a Citizen Maister Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: No faith not yet— Boy!

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: What must you doe with a Citizen sir?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: A custome they're bound to alate by the default of euill debters, no Citizen must lend money without two bee bound in the bond, the second Man enters but for custome sake.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: No, and must hee needes be a Citizen?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Byth masse stay, ile learne that Maister Quomodo!

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p:
Must the second partie that enters into bond onely for fashions sake needs be a Citizen? what say you to this Gentleman
for one?

sp.speaker: Quomo.
sp.p: A lasse sir, you know hee's a meere stranger to me, I neither am sure of his going or abiding, hee may Inne heere to Night, and ride away to morrow, (although I graunt the chiefe burden lyes vpon you) yet wee are bound to make choice of those we know sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Why hee's a Gentleman of a prettie liuing sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: It may be so: yet vnder both your pardons I'de rather haue a Citizen.

sp.speaker: Easie.
sp.p: I hope you wil not disparadge me so? tis wel known I haue three hundred pound a yeare in Essex,

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Well saide, to him thy selfe, take him vp roundly.

sp.speaker: Easie.
sp.p: And how doubtfullie so ere you account of me, I doe not thinke but I might make my bond passe for a hundred pound 'ith Citie.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What alone sir?

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: Alone sir: who saies so? perhaps ide send downe for a Tennant or too.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I, that's another case sir.

sp.speaker: Easie.
sp.p: Another case let it be then.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Nay, grow not into anger sir.

sp.speaker: Easie.
sp.p: Not take me into a Bond, as good as you shall good man Goose-cap.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Wel Maister Blastfield, because I wil not disgrace the Gentleman, i'me content for once, but we must not make a practise on't.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: No sir, now you would you shall not.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Cuds me, i'me vndone, hee's gone agen.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: The Netts broke.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Hold there deere Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Easie.
sp.p: Deny me that small curtizie? s'foot a very Iew will not deny it me.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Now must I catch him warily.

sp.speaker: Easie.
sp.p: A iest indeede, not take me into a Bond quo they.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Maister Easie— Marke my words, if it stood not vppon the eternall losse of thy credit against Supper—

sp.speaker: Easie.
sp.p: Masse that's true.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: The pawning of thy horse for his owne Vittailes.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Right yfaith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And thy vtter dissolution amongest Gentlemen for euer.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Pox on't.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Quomodo should hang, rot, stinke.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Sweete boy yfaith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Drop Dam.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Excellent Shortyard.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I forgot all this: what meant I to swagger before I had money in my purse? how do's maister Quomodo? is the Bond readie?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Oh sir.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Come we must be friends, heer's my hand.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Giue it the Scriuener: here he comes.

sp.speaker: Dust.
sp.p: Good day Maister Quomodo, good morrow Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: We must require a little ayde from your pen, good master Dustbox.

sp.speaker: Dust.
sp.p: What be the Gentlemens names that are bound sir?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Master Iohn Blastfield Esquire ith wilde of Kent, and what doe they call your bed fellowes name?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Maister Richard Easie: you may easily hit on't.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Master Richard Easie of Essex Gentleman, both bound to Ephestian Quomodo Citizen and Draper of London: the summe two hundred pound. What Time doe you take master Blastfield for the payment?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I neuer passe my Month you know.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I know it sir. October sixteenth to day, sixteenth of Nouember say.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Is it your custome to returne so soone sir?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I neuer misse you.

div.stage: Enter Falslight like a Porter, sweating.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I am come for the rest of the same price master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Star-marke, this is it, are all the rest gone?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thei'r all at Master Stilyard downes by this time.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: How the poore raskall's all in a froth?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Push, their ordaind to sweate for Gentlemen,— Porters backes and womens bellies beare vp the world.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Tis true yfaith, they beare men and money, and that's the world.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Ye'aue found it sir.

sp.speaker: Dust.
sp.p: I'me readie to your hands Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Come Master Easie.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: It shall be yours I say.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Nay pray master Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I will not yfaith.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: What doe you meane sir?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I should shew little bringing vp, to take the way of a stranger.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: By my troth you doe your selfe wrong tho maister Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Not a whit sir.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: But to auoid strife, you shall haue your will of mee for once.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Let it be so I pray.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Now I begin to set one foote vppon the lande, mee thinkes I am felling of Trees alreadie, wee shall haue some Essex Loggs yet to keepe Christmasse with, and that's a comfort.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Now is he quarting out the Executioner.
Strides ouer him: with his owne blood he writes:
I am no Dame that can endure such sights.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: So his right wing is cut, will not flie farre
Past the two Cittie hazards, Poultrie, and Woodstreete.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: How like you my Roman hand yfaith?

sp.speaker: Dust.
sp.p: Exceeding well sir, but that you rest too much vpon your R. and make your ease too little.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Ile mend that presently.

sp.speaker: Dust.
sp.p: Nay tis done now, past mending: you both deliuer this to maister Quomodo as your deede?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: We doe sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I thanke you Gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Would the Coyne would come away now, we haue deseru'd for't

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: By your leaue a little Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How now? what's the matter? speake?

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: As fast as I can sir— All the cloathes come backe agen.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What's the newes?

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: The passage to Middle borrow is stopt, and therefore neither Maister Stilliard-downe, nor Maister Beggerland, nor any other Merchant wil deliuer present money vppon't.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why what hard lucke haue you Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Why Maister Blastfield?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Pish—

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: You'r so discontented too presently, a man cannot tell how to speake to you?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why what would you say?

sp.speaker: Ea.
sp.p: We must make some what on't now sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I where? how? the best is it lyes all vppon my necke, Maister Quomodo, can you help me to any money fort? speak

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Troth Maister Blastfield, since my selfe is so vnfurnisht, I knowe not the meanes how, there's one 'ith streete a new setter vp, if any lay out money vppon't twill be he.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: His name:

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Master Idem— but you know we cannot giue but greatly to your losse, because we gaine and liue by't.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Sfoo't will he giue any thing.

sp.speaker: Ea.
sp.p: I, stand vppon that.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Will he giue any thing?— the Brokers will giue nothing? to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Falslight.

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: Ouer your head sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Desire Maister Idem to come presently and looke vppo'th cloath.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What if hee should offer but a hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: If he want twentie on't lets take it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Ea.
sp.p: Maister Quomodo we wil haue foure or fiue hundred pound for you of his owne within three or foure daies.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Tis true, he saide so indeede.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Is That your wife maister Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: That's shee, little Tomazin?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Vnder your leaue sir, ile show my selfe a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Doe, and welcome Maister Easie.

sp.speaker: Ea.
sp.p: I haue commission for what I doe Lady from your Husband.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: You may haue a stronger commission for the next, an't please you, that's from my selfe.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: You teach me the best law Lady.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Beshrew my blood, a proper, springfull, and a sweet Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: My Sonne: Sim Quomodo? heere's more worke for you Maister Easie, you must salute him too, for hee's like to be heire of thy land I can tell thee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Vim, vitam, sprinque salutem.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He showes you there he was a Cambridge man sir, but now hee's a Templer, ha's he not good grace to make a Lawyer?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: A very good grace to make a Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: For indeede he ha's no grace at all.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Some gaue me counsell to make him a Diuine.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Fye, fie.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: But some of our liuerie thinke it an vnfit thing, that our owne Sonnes should tell vs of our vices: others, to make him a Phisitian, but then being my heyre, i'me afraide hee would make me away: now a Lawyer thei'r all willing too, because tis good for our trade and encreaseth, the number of Cloath-gownes, and indeede tis the fittest for a Citizens Sonne, for our word is, what doe yee lacke? and their word is what doe you giue.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: Exceeding propper.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Maister Idem welcome.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I haue seene the cloath sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Verie well.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I am but a yong setter vp, the vttermost I dare ventture vppon 'tis three-score pound.

sp.speaker: Shs.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: If it be for me, so, I am for it: if not, you haue your doth and I haue my money.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: Nay, pray maister Blastfield refuse not his kinde offer.

sp.speaker: Shs.
sp.p: A bargaine then maister Idem, clap hands— hee's finely cheated: come, let's all to the next Tauerne and see the money paide.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I follow you Gentlemen, take my Sonne along with you.

Now to my keyes: i'me Maister Idem, hee must fetch the money, first haue I caught him in a bond for two hundred pound, and my two hundred poundes worth a doath agen for three-score pound: admire me all you studyents at Innes for cousenage.

div.head: Incipit Actus Tertius.
div.stage: Enter Lethes pander, Helgill, the Caūtrie wench comming in with a new fashion Gawne drest Gentlewoman like, the Taylor pointes it, and a Tyrewoman busie about her head.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: You talke of an alteration, heer's the thing it selfe, what base birthe does not rayment make glorious? and what glorious birthes do not ragges make infamous? why should not a woman confesse what she is now? since the finest are but deluding shadowes, begot betweene Tyrewomen and Taylors? for instance, beholde their Parents.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: Say what you wil, this wire becomes you best, how say you Taylor?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I promise you tis a wire would draw mee from my worke seauen daies a weeke.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Why doe you worke a sundaies Taylor?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Hardest of al a Sundaie, because we are most forbidden

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Troth and so doe moste of vs women, the better day the better deede we thinke.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: Excellent exceeding yfaith, a narrow card wyer sets out a cheeke so fat and so full, and if you be rulde by me, you shal weare your hayre still like a Mock-face behinde, tis such an Italian world, many men knowe not Before from Behinde.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: How like you the fitting of this gowne now Mistris Comings?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: It sits at meruailous good Ease, and comely discretion.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Who would thinke now this fine Sophisticated squal came out of the Bosome of a Barne, and the loynes of a Haytosser.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Out you sawcie pestiferous Pander, I scorne that yfaith.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Excellent, already the true phrase and stile of a strumpet, stay, a little more of the red, and then I take my leaue of your Cheeke for foure & twenty houres— Doe you not thinke it impossible that her owne Father should know her now, if he saw her?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Why I thinke no lesse, how can he knowe me, when I scarce knowe my selfe.

sp.speaker: Helg:
sp.p: Tis right.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: But so well you lay waite for a man for me.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: I protest I haue bestowed much labour about it, and in fit Time, good newes I hope.

div.stage: Enter one bringing in her Father in disguise to serue her.
div.p: 1 Iu'e found one yet at last, in whose preferment I hope to reape credit.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Is that the fellowe?
1 Lady it is.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Art thou willing to serue me fellow?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: So please you, he that ha's not the heart to serue such a Mistris as your beautifull selfe, deserues to be honoured for a foole, or Knighted for a Coward.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: There's to many of them alreadie.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Twere sinne then to raise the number.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Well, weele trie both our likings for a month, and then eyther proceede, or let fall the suite.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Be it as you haue spoke, but tis my hope A longer Tearme.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: No truely, our Tearme endes once a month, wee should get more then the Lawyers, for they haue but foure Tearmes a yeare, and wee haue twelue, & that makes e'm run so fast to vs in the Vacation.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: A mistris of of a choice beauty, amongst such imperfect creatures I ha not seene a perfecter: I should haue reckoned the fortunes of my Daughter amongst the happiest, had she lighted into such a seruice, whereas now I rest doubt full, whome or where she serues.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: There's for your bodily aduice Taylor, and theres for your head-counsell, and I discharge you both till to morrowe morning agen.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: At which time our neatest Attendance.

sp.speaker: Coin.
sp.p: I pray haue an especiall care howsoeuer you stand or lye, that nothing fall vppon your haire to batter your wire.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I warrant you for that— which Gowne becomes me best now, the purple Sattin or this?

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: If my opinion might rule ouer you—

div.stage: Enter Lethe with Rerage and Salewood.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Come gallants, ile bring you to a Beauty shal stricke your eyes into your hearts, what you see you shall desire, yet neuer enioy.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And that's a Villanous torment.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: And is she but your vnderput Maister Lethe?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: No more of my credit, and a Gentlewoman of a great house, Noble parentage, vnmatchable Education, my plain Pung. I may, grace her with the name of a Curtizan, a Backslider, a Prostitution, or such a Toy, but when all comes to al tis but a plaine Pung, looke you Gentlemen, that's she, beholde her.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Oh my beloued strayer! I consume in thy absence.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: La you now— you shall not say ile be proud to you Gentlemen, I giue you leaue to salute her, I me afraide of nothing now, but that sheele vtterlie disgrace e'm, turn taile to e'm, and place their kisses behinde her, no by my faith, she deceiues me, by my troth sha's kist am both with her lips: I thanke you for that musick maisters, sli'd they both court her at once, and see if she ha not the wit to stand still and let e'm: I thinke if two men were brewde into one, there is that woman would drink e'm vp both.

sp.speaker: Rerg.
sp.p: A Cockscombe, he a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: He saies he ha's a place there.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: So ha's the Foole a better place then he, and can come where he dare not show his head.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Nay, he are you me Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: I protest you were the last man we spoke on, we're a little busie yet, pray stay there a while, weele come to you presently.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: This is good yfaith, indure this and be a slaue foreuer, since you neither sauour of good breeding nor bringing vp, Ile slice your hamstrings but ile make you show mannerly— pox on you, leaue courting, I ha not the heart to hurt an Englishman yfaith, or else—

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Prethee lets be merrie, nothing else— heere, fetch some wine.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Let my Seruant goe for't.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Your's, which is he?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: This sir, but I scarce like my Mistris now: the loynes can nere be safe where the Flyes be so busie— Witte by experience bought foyles wit at Schoole: Who proues a deeper knaue then a Spent foole, I am gone for your worships wine sir.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Sir, you put vp too much indignitie, bring company to cut your owne throate, the fire is not yet so hot, that you neede two Screenes before it, tis but new kindled yet, if twere risse to a flame, I could not blame you then to put others before you but alasse all the heate yet is comfortable a cherrisher, not a defacer.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Prethe let e'm alone, theile bee asham'd o't anon I troe, if they haue any grace in 'em.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Ide faine haue him quarrell, fight, and be assuredlye kild, that I might beg his place: for there's nere a one voide yet.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Youle make him mad anon.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: Tis to that end.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Yet at last, Maister Quomodo is as firme as his promise.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Did I not tell you still he would.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Let me see, I am seauen hundred pound in bond now to the Rascall.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Nay y'are no lesse Maister Blastfield, looke too't, by my troth, I must needes confesse sir, you ha bene vncommonly kinde to me, since I ha beene in Towne, but maister Alsup shall know on't.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: That's my Ambition sir.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I beseech you sir. Stay, this is Lethes haunt, see, we haue catcht him.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Maister Blastfield and Maister Easie, y'are kinde Gentlemen both.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Is that the beauty you famde so?

sp.speaker: Leeh.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Who be those so industrious about her?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Rerage and Salewood: Ile tell you the vnmannerlyest tricke of e'm, that euer you heard in your life.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Prethee whats that?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: I enuyted e'm hyther to looke vpon her, brought e'm along with me, gaue e'm leaue to salute her in kindnes, what doe they but moste sawcilie fall in loue with her, verye impudently court her for themselues, and like two craftye Atturneyes, finding a hole in my lease, goe about to defeate me of my right.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Ha they so little conscience?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: The moste vnciuilst part that you haue seene, I know theile be sorry for't when they haue done, for ther's no man but giues a sigh after his sin of women, I knowe it by my selfe.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: You parcell of a rude, sawcie and vnmannerly nation.

sp.speaker: Lethe.
sp.p: One good thing in him, heele tell e'm ont roundly.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Cannot a Gentleman purchase a little fire to thawe his appetite by, but must you that haue beene dayly sindg'd in the flame, be as greedy to beguile him on't? how can it appeare in you but maliciously, and that you goe about to engrosse hell to your selues? heauen forbid, that you should not suffer a stranger to come in, the Deuill himselfe is not so vnmannerly, I doe not thinke but some of them rather will be wise enough to beg Offices there before you, and keepe you out, marry all the spite will bee they cannot sell e'm agen.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Come, are you not to blame— not to giue place?— To vs I meane—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: A worse and a worse disgrace.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Nay Gentlemen, you wrong vs both then, stand from me, I protest ile draw my siluer Bodkin vpon you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Clubs, clubs,— Gentlemen stand vppon your Guard.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman must swagger a little now and then I perceiue, there would bee no ciuilitie in her Chamber else, though it be my hard fortune to haue my keeper there a coward, the thing that's kept is a Gentlewoman borne.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And to conclude a Coward, infallible of your side, why doe you thinke yfaith I tooke you to be a Coward? doe I thinke youle turne your backe to anye man liuing? youle be whipt first.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: And then indeede she turnes her backe to some man liuing.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: But that man showes himselfe a Knaue, for he dares not showe his owne face when hee does it, for some of the common Counsell in Henry the eights daies thought it modestie at that time, that one Vizzard should looke vppon another.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: Twas honestly considered of e'm yfaith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How now? what peece of stuffe comes heere?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Now some good newes yet to recouer my Repute, and grace me in this company; Gentlemen, are we friendes among our selues?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Vnited.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Then heere comes Reuish to confirme our Amitie— Wag-tail, salute them all they are friendes.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Then sauing my quarrell to you all.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Toe's all

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Now be shrowe your hearts, and you doe not.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: To sweete Maister Lethe.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Let it flow this way deere Maister Blastfield, Gentlemen to you all.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: This Renish wine is like the scowring-sticke to a gun, it makes the Barrell cleere: it ha's an excelent vertue, it keepes all the Sinckes in man and womans bodie sweete in Iune and Iuly, and to say truth, if Ditches were not cast once a yeare, and Drabs once a Month, there would be no abiding i'th Cittie.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Gentlemen, ile make you priuie to a letter I sent.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A letter comes well after priuie, it makes amends.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: There's one Quomodo, a Drapers Daughter in towne whome for her happie portion I wealthily affect.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And not for loue? this makes for me his Riuall, beare witnesse.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: The Father does elect me for the man, The Daughter sayes the same.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Are you not well?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: Yes all but for the mother, shee's my sicknesse.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Birlady and the Mother is a pestilent, wilfull, troublesome sicknesse I can tell you, if she light vpon you handsomlye.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I finde it so: she for a stranger pleades: Whose name I ha not learn'd.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And ene now he cald me by it.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Now as my letter tolde her, since onely her consent kept aloofe of, what might I thinke on't, but that she meerely dooted vpon me herselfe.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Very assuredly.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: This makes still for you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Did you let it goe so yfaith?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: You may beleeue it sir, now what sayes her answere?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I, her answere.

sp.speaker: Gruil.
sp.p: She saies you'r a base proud knaue, and like your worship.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Nay, heare out hir answere, or there's no goodnesse in you.

sp.speaker: Grui.
sp.p: You ha forgot she saies in what pickle your worship came vp, and brought two of your friendes to giue their wordes for a sute of greene Kersye.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Drudge, peace, or—

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Show your selfe a Gentleman, she had the patience to reade your letter which was as bad as this can be, what will she thinke on't, not heare her answere? speake, good his drudge.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: And as for hir Daughter, shee hopes sheele be rulde by her in time, and not be carryed away with a cast of Manchets, a bottle of Wine, and a Custard, which once made her Daughter sicke, because you came by it with a bad conscience.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Gentlemen, i'me all in a sweate.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: That's verie wholsome for your body, nay you must keepe in your armes.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Then she demaunded of me whether I was your worships Ant or no?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Out, out, out, Gru. Alasse saide I, I am a poore drudge of his.

div.p: Faith and thou wert his Mother (quoth she) heed make thee his Drudge I warrant him—
Marry out vpon him (quoth I) an't like your worship.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Horror, horror, i'me smother'd, let me goe, torment me not.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And you loue me, lets follow him Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I count a hundred pound wel spent to persue a good iest Maister Easie.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: By my troth I begin to beare that minde too.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Well saide yfaith, hang money-good iests are worth siluer at all times.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: They'r worth golde Maister Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Doe you deceiue me so? are you toward marriage yfaith Master Lethe it shall goe hard but ile forbid the Banes, ile send a messenger into your bones, another into your pursse but Ile doo't.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Thou faire and wicked Creature, steept in Arte,
Beautious and fresh, the soule the fowlest part.
A common Filth, is like a House possest,
Where if not spoild, youle come out fraide at least,
This seruice likes not me, though I rest poore,
I hate the basest vse to screene a whore.
The humaine stroke nere made him, hee that can
Be Bawde to Woman, neuer leapt from man.
Some monster wunne his Mother,
I wisht my poore childe hether, doubled wrong,
A month and such, a mistris were too long,
Yet heere a while in others liues ile see,
How former follyes, did appeare in me.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Anon sir.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Where left you Maister Blastfield your maister, say you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: An houre since I left him in Paules sir— but youle not finde him the same man agen next time you meete him.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Methinks I haue noe beeing without his companie tis so full of kindenes and delight, I holde him to be the onely Companyon in earth.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I, as Companions goe now adaies that helpe to spend a mans money.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: So full of nimble wit, various discourse, praegnant apprehension, and vncommon entertainment, hee might keepe Company with any Lord for his grace.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I, with any Lord that were past it.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p:
And such a good free hearted honest, affable kinde of
Gentleman: Come Boy a heauinesse will possesse me till I see him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But youle finde your selfe heauyer then, by a seauen hundred pound weight,— Alasse poore Birds that cannot keepe the sweete Countrie, where they slye at pleasure, but must needes come to London to haue their wings clipt, and are faine to goe hopping home agen.

div.stage: Enter Shortyard and Falslight like a Sarieant and a Yeoman to arrest Easie.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: So, No man is so impudent to denye that— Spirits can change their shapes, and soonest of all into Serjeants: because they are Coosen Germans to spirits, for there's but two kinde of arrests till Doomes-day, the Deuill for the soule, the Serjeant for the body, but afterward the deuill arrests bodye and soule Serjeant & all, if they be knaues still, and deserue it, now my yeoman Falslight.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I Attend you good Serjant Shortyard.

sp.speaker: Shor.
sp.p: No more maister Blastfield now— poore Easie hardly be set.

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: But how if he should goe to prison, weere in a madde state then, being not Serjeants.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Neuer let it come neere thy beleeue that heele take prison, or stand out in lawe, knowing the debt to be due, but still expect the presence of Maister Blastfield, kinde M. Blastfield, worshipfull M Blastfield— and at the last—

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Maister Shortyard, maister Falslight.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: The Boy: a warning-piece,— see where he comes.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Is not in paules.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He is not farre off sure sir.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: When was his hovre sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Two sir.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Why two ha's strucke.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No sir, they are now a striking.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Maister Richard Easie of Essex we arrest you.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Alasse a Surgeon, hee's hurt ith shoulder.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Deliuer your weapons quietly sir.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Y'are arrested at the suite of M. Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Maister Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How strange you make it, you'r a landed Gentleman sir, I knew tis but a trifle, a bond of seauen hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: La, I knowe you had mistooke, you should arrest One Maister Blastfield, tis his bond, his debt.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Is not your name there?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: True, for fashions sake.

sp.speaker: Sho.
