sp.p: Why and tis for fashions sake that we arrest you.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Nay, & it be no more, I yeelde to that: I know Maister Blastfield wil see me take no iniurie as long as i'me in towne, for Maister Alsups sake.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Whos's that Sir?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: An honest Gentleman in Essex.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Oh, In Essex! I thought you had beene in London, where now your busines lyes, honestye from Essex will be a great while a comming sir, you should looke out an honest paire of Cittizens.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Alasse sir, I knowe not where to finde e'm.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: No, there's enow in Towne.

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: I know not one by my troth, I am a meere stranger for these partes, Maister Quomodo is all, and the honestest that I knowe.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: To him then lets set forward:— Yeoman Spiderman, cast an eye about for Maister Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Boy— Alasse the poore boy was frighted away at first.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Can you blame him sir— we that dayly fray away Knight's, may fright away Boyes I hope.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Ha? haue they him sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: As sure as—

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: The land's mine, thats sure enough boy.
Let me aduaunce thee knaue, and giue thee a kisse,
My plot's so firme I dare it now to misse.
Now shall I be diuulgde a landed man,
Throughout the liuerie:— one points, another whispers,
A third frets inwardly: let him fret and hang,
Especially his enuie I shall haue,
That would be faine, yet cannot be a knaue,
Like an olde leather girt in furde Gowne,
Whose minde stands stiffe but his performance downe.
Now come my golden daies in:— whither is the worshipfull
master Quomodo, and his faire Bedfellow rid forth,
To his land in Essex? whence comes those goodly loade of
Logs? from his land in Essex? where growes this pleasant
fruit, sayes one Citizens wife in the rowe; at maister Quomodos
Orchard in Essex; oh, oh, do's it so, I thanke you for
that good newes yfaith.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here they come with him sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Grant mee patience in my ioyes, that being so great I run not mad with 'em.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Blesse maister Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How now Serjeants? who ha you brought me here, master Easie?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Why la you now Serjeants, did I not tell you you mistooke?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Did you not heare me say. I had rather ha had master Blastfield, the more sufficient man a great deale?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Verie true sir,— but this Gentleman lighting into our hands first—

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why did you so sir?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Wee thought good to make vse of that oportunitie, and hold him fast.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: You did well in that I must needes say, for your owne securities, but twas not my minde master Easie to haue you first, you must needes thinke so.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I dare sweare that master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: But since you are come to me, I haue no reason to refuse you, I should show little manners in that sir.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p:
But I hope you spake not in that sence sir, to impose
the bond vpon mee.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: By my troth that's my meaning sir, you shall finde mee an honest man, you see I meane what I say, is not the day past, the money vntendred, you'd ha me liue vprightly maister Easie?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Why sir, you know maister Blastfield is the man.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why sir, I know master Blastfield is the man, but is he any more then one man? two entred into bond to mee, or I'me fowly coozn'd.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: You know my entrance was but for fashion sake.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why, ile a gree to you, you'l grant tis the fashion likewise when the Bond's due to haue the money paid agen.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: So we told him sir, and that it lay in your worships curtezie to arrest which you please.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Marie do's it sir, these fellowes know the law,— beside, you offred yourself into Bond to me you know, when I had no stomake to you, now beshrew your heart for your labour, I might ha had a good substantiall Citizen, that would ha paid the summe roundly, altho I think you sufficient enough for seauen hundred pound, beside the forfeyture, I would be loath to disgrace you so much before Serjeants.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: If you would hathe pacience sir, I doe not thinke but master Blasefield is at Carriers to receiue the money.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He wil proue the honester man then, & you the better discharged, I wonder he should breake with me, t'was neuer his practise, you must not bee angry with mee now, tho you were somewhat hot when you entred into Bond, you may easily go in angerly, but you cannot come out so.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: No, the Diuels in't for that.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Do you heere sir, a my troth we pittie you, ha you any store of Crownes about you?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Faith a poore store, yet they shall be at their seruice that will striue to doe me good,— we were both drunke last night, and neer thought vpon the bond.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I must tell you this, you haue fell in to the hands of a most mercilesse deuourer, the verie gul athe citie, should you offer him mony, Goods or lands now, hee'd rather haue your bodie in prison, hee's a such a nature. Eas. Prison w'are vndon then.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Hee's a such a nature, looke?— Let him owe any man a spite! what's his course: he will lend him mony to day, a purpose to rest him tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Defend me?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Has at least sixteene at this instant proceeded in both the Counters: some batchler, some masters, some doctors of captiuitie of 20. years standing and he desires nothing more then imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Would Ma. Blastfield would come away.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I, then things would not bee as they are— what will you say to vs if wee procure you two substantiall subsidie Cittizens to baile you spite on's heart, and set you at libertie to finde out maister Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Serjeant! here, take all, ile be deare to you, doe but performe it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Much.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Inough sweet Serjeant, I hope I vnderstand thee.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I loue to preuent the malice of such a rascall, perhaps you might find maister Blastfield to night.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Why, we lie together man, there's the iest on't.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Fie.— and youle seeke to secure your baile, because they will be two Cittizens of good account, you must doe that for your credit sake.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Ile be bound to saue them harmelesse.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A pox on him, you cut his throte then,— no words.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: What's it you require me maister Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: You know that before this time I hope sir, present money, or present imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I told you so.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: We nere had money of you.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: You had commodities, an't please you

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Well, may I not craue so much libertie vpon my word, to seeke out maister Blastfield?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Yes, and you would not laugh at me: wee are sometimes Gulls to Gentlemen, I thanke 'em; but Gentlemen are neuer Gulls to vs, I commend 'em.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p:
Vnder your leaue master Quomodo, the Gentleman craues the furtherance of an houre, and it sorts well with our
occasion at this time, hauing a little vrgent busines at Guild-hall, at which minute weele returne, and see what agreement is made.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Nay take him along with you Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I'me vndone then.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Hee's your prisoner; and being safe in your house at your owne disposing, you cannot denie him such a request: beside, he hath a little faith in Ma. Blastfields comming sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Let me not be too long delaid I charge you.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Not an houre yfaith sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O maister Easie, of all men liuing I neuer dream you would ha done me this iniurie: make me would my credite, faile in my commodities, ring my state into suspition: for the breaking of your day to me, has broken my day to others.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: You tell me of that still, which is no fault of mine master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Oh whats a man but his honestie master Easie, and thats a fault amongst most of vs all,— Marke but this note, Ile giue you good counsell now,— as often as you giue your name to a bond, you must think you christen a child, and take the charge on't too: for as the one, the bigger it growes the more cost it requires: so the other the longer it lies, the more charges it puts you too, onely heer's the difference a childe must bee broke, and a bond must not, the more you breake children, the more you keep 'em vnder: but the more you breake bondes, the more theyle leape in your face, and therefore, to conclude, I would neuer vndertake to bee Gossip to that bond which I would not see well brought vp.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Say you so sir?— Ile thinke vpon your counsaile hereafter for't.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Ah foole, thou shouldest neere ha tasted such witte but that I know tis too late.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: The more I grieue:

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: To put all this into the compasse of a litle hoop Ring
Make this account, come better dayes or worse,
So many bonds abroad, so many boyes at nurse.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p:
A good medicine for a short memorie:— but since,
you haue entred so farre, whose children are desperate depts I pray?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Faith they are like the of-springs of stolne lust, put to the hospital, their fathers are not to be found, they are either too far abroad, or too close within, and thus for your memories sake.
sp.l: The desperate Debter hence deriues his name,
One that has neither money, land nor fame,
All that he makes, proue Bastards, and not Bonds,
But such as yours, at first are borne to lands.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: But all that I beget heereafter Ile so one disinherit Maister Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: In the meane time heeres a shrewd knaue will disinherit you.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Well, to put you out of all doubt Maister Quomodo, ile not trust to your curtezie, I ha sent for bayle.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How? y'aue couzened me there yfaith.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Since the worst comes to the worst, I haue those friends 'ith Cittie, I hope that will not suffer me to lye for seauen hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: And you tolde me you had no friendes heere at all, how should a man trust you now?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: That was but to trie your Curtesie M. Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How vnconscionably he gulls himself— they must be wealthye subsidie-men sir, at least fortye pound 'ith Kings Bookes I can tell you, that doe such a feate for you.

div.stage: Enter Shortyard and Falslight, like wealthy Cittizens in Sattin sutes.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Heere they come what so ere they are.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Berlady Aldermans Deputies, I am verie sorrye for you sir, I cannot refuse such men.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Are you the Gentleman in distresse?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: None more then my selfe sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Hee speakes truer then he thinkes, for if he knew, The hearts that owe those faces— a darke shop's good for somewhat.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: That was all sir.

sp.speaker: Shor.
sp.p: And that's enough, for by that meanes you haue made your selfe liable to the Bond, as well as that Basefield

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Blastfield sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Oh crie you mercie tis Blastfield indeede.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: But vnder both your worships fauours I know where to finde him presently.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: That's all your refuge.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Newes, good newes Master Easie.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: What boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Maister Blastfield my maister has receiued a thousand pound, and will be at his lodging at supper.

sp.speaker: Easie.
sp.p: Happye newes, heare you that Maister Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Tis enough for you to heare that, y'are the fortunate man sir.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Not now I beseech your good worships.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Gentleman, what's your tother name?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Easie.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: O Maister Easie— I would we could rather pleasure you otherwise Maister Easie, you should soone perceiue it, ile speake a proud word we haue pittied more Gentlemen in distresse, then any two Cittizens within the freedome— but to be baile to seauen hundred pound action, is a matter of shroud weight.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Ile be bound to secure you.

sp.speaker: Shor.
sp.p: Tut, what's your bond sir?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Bodye, goods, and Lands, immediately before Master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Shall we venture once agen, that haue beene so often vndone by Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I haue no great stomacke too't, it will appeare in vs more pittie then wisdome.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Why should you say so sir?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I like the Gentlemans face well, hee doe's not looke as if he would deceiue vs.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: O not I sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p:
Come weele make a desperate voyage once agen,
weele trye his honestie, and take his single bond, of body Goods and Lands.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I dearely thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Maister Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Your worships.

sp.speaker: Shortyard.
sp.p: We haue tooke a Course to set your prisoner free.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Your worships are good baile you content me.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Come then, and be a witnesse to a Recullisance.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: With all my heart sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Maister Easie, you must haue an especiall care now to find out that Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I shall haue him at my lodging sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: The suite will bee followed against you else, Maister Quomodo will come vpon vs, and forsake you.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I know that sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Well since I see you haue such a good minde to bee honest, Ile leaue some greater affayres, and sweate with you to finde him my selfe.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Heare then my miserie ends. A strangers kindenesse oft exceedes a friends.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Thou art deceiu'd thy miserie but begins,
"To beguile goodnes, is the coare of sins.
My loue is such vnto thee, that I die
As often as thou drink'st vp iniurie,
Yet haue no meanes to warne thee from't, for hee
" That sowes in Craft, doe's rape in Iealousie.

sp.speaker: Rerrage.
sp.p: Now the letters made vp and all, it wants but the print of a seale, and away it goes to Maister Quomodo: Andrew Lethe is well whipt in't, his name stands in a white sheete heere, and does pennance for him.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: You haue shame enough against him, if that be good.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: First as a contempt of that reuerend Ceremony, hee has in hand, to wit, marriage.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: Why doe you say to wit marriage, when you knowe theres none will marrie that's wise.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Had it not more neede then, to haue wit to put too't if it be growne to a Folly?

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: Y'aue wun, Ile giue't you.

sp.speaker: Rerag.
sp.p: Tis no thankes now,— but as I was saying: as a soule contempt to that sacred ceremony, hee moste audaciouslye keepes a Drab in towne, and to be free from the interruption of blew Beadles, and other bawdy Officers, hee most politickly lodges her in a Constables house.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: That's a prettie point yfaith.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And so the watch that should fetch her out, are her chiefest guard to keepe her in.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: It must needes be for looke how the Constable playes his Conscience, the watch-men will followe the suite.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Why well then.

div.stage: Enter Easie with Shortyard like a Cittizen.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: All night from me hee's hurt, hee's made away.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Where shall we seeke him now? you leade me fayre daunt's sir.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Pray keepe a little patience sir, I shall finde him at last you shall see.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A Cittizen of my ease and substance to walke so long a foote.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: You should ha had my horse but that he ha's eaten out his head sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How would you had me hold him by the tayle sir then?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Manners forbid, tis no part of my meaning sir,— oh heere's Maister Rerage, and Maister Salewood, now we shall heare of him presently:— Gentlemen both.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: Maister Easie, how fare you sir?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Verye well in health, did you see Maister Blastfield this morning?

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: I was about to moue it to you.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: We were all three in a minde then.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: I ha not set eye on him these two daies.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: I wonder he keepes so long from vs yfaith.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I began to be sicke.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Nothing in troth, but a great desire I had to haue seene him.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: I wonder you shuld misse on't lately, you'r his bedfelow

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I lay alone to night yfaith,— I doe not know how, O here comes master Lethe, he can dispatch me: Master Lethe!

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: What's your name sir?— O crie you mercie master Easie.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: When parted you from maister Blastfield sir?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Blastfield's an Asse, I haue sought him these two dayes to beate him.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Your selfe all alone sir?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: I, and three more.—

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I am glad, I am where I am then, I perceiue twas time of all handes.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Content yfaith, let's trace him.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What? haue you found him yet? neither? what's to be done now? ile venter my bodie no further for any Gentlemans pleasure, I know not how soone I may be cald vppon, and now to ouer-heate my selfe.—

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Ime vndone.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: This is you that slept with him, you can make fooles of vs, but ile turne you ouer to Quomodo fort.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Ile preuent mine owne danger.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Tho I loue Gentlemen well, I doe not meane to bee vndone for 'em.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Pray sir, let mee request you sir, sweete sir, I beseech you sir.

div.head: Incipit quartus.
div.stage: Enter Quomodo, his disguised spirits, after whom Easie followes hard.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Made fooles of vs! not to be found!

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What, what?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Do not vndoe me quite tho Ma Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Y'are verie welcome, master Easie, I ha nothing to say to you, ile not touch you, you may goe when you please,— I haue good baile here I thanke their worships.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: What shall I say, or whom shall I beseech?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Gentlemen, S'lid they were borne to vndo vs I think, but for my part, Ile make an oath before maister Qomodo here, nere to doe Gentlemen good while I liue.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Ile not be long behind you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Away; if you had any grace in you, you would bee ashamed to looke vs ith face, ywis I wonder with what browe you can come amongst vs, I should seeke my fortunes farre enough if I were you, and neither returne to Essex, to bee a shame to my predecessors, nor remaine about London, to be a mocke to my successors.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Subtle Shortyard!

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Here are his lands forfeyted to vs master Quomodo, and to auoyd the inconscionable trouble of law, all the assistance he made to vs, we willingly resigne to you.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What shall I doe with Rubbish, giue me money: Tis for your worships to haue land, that keepe great houses, I should be hoysted.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: But master Quomodo, if you would but conceyue it aright, the land would fall fitter to you then to vs.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Curtzing about my land.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: You haue a towardly sonne and heyre as we heare.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I must needs say, he is a Templer indeed.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: We haue neither posteritie in Towne nor hope for any abroad; we haue wiues, but the markes haue beene out of their mouths these twentie yeares, and as it appeares, they did little good when they were in: wee could not stande about it sir, to get riches and children too, tis more then one man can doe. And I am of those Citizens mindes that say, let our wiues make shift for children and they will, they get none of vs; and I cannot thinke, but he that has both much wealth and many children, has had more helpes comming in then himselfe.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I am not a Bowe wide of your minde sir.— And for the thristie and couetous hopes I haue in my sonne and heyre Sim Qmomodo, that hee will neuer trust his land in Waxe and Parchment as many Gentlemen haue done before him.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Al y-blow for me.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I will honestly discharge you, and recevue it in due forme and order of law, to strengthen it for euer to my sonne and heyre, that he may vndoubtedly enter vppon't without the let or molestation of any man, at his or our pleasure whensoeuer.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Tis so assurde vnto you.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why then maister Basie y'are a freeman sir, you may deale in what you please, and goe whether you will. Why Tomazin, maister Easie is come from Essex, bid him welcome in a cup of small Beare.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Not onely vilde, but in it tyrannous.

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: If it please you sir, you knowe the house, you may visite vs often, and dine with vs once a quarter.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.l: Confusion light on you, your wealth and heyre,
Worme gnaw your conscience, as the Moth your ware,
I am not the first heyre that rob'd, or beg'd.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Excellent excellent, sweet Spirits.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Landed maister Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: Delicate shortyard, commodious Falslight,
Hug and away, shift, shift.
Tis slight, not strength that giues the greatest lift.
Nowe my desires are full— for this tyme,
Men may haue Cormorant wishes, but alas
A little thing three hundred pound a yeare,
Suffices nature, keepes life and soule together,
Ile haue 'em kept immediately.
sp.p:
I long to warme my selfe by'th wood,— A fine iourney in the Whitsun-holy dayes yfaith, to ride downe with a number of Citizens, and their wiues, some vpon pillions, some vpon Side saddles, I, and little Tomazin ith middle our some and heire Sim Quomodo in a peach colour Taffata Iacket, some horses length, or a long yard before vs, there will be a fine shew on's I can tell you, where we Citizens will laugh, and lie downe get all our wiues with child against a bank and get vp againe,— stay, ha hast thou that wit yfaith twill be admirable, to see how the very thought of greene fieldes puts a man into sweet inuenttions. I will presently possesse Sim
Quomodo of all the land, I haue a toy and Ile doo't: and because I see before mine eies that most of our heires proue notorious Rioters after our deaths, and that cousonage in the father wheeles about to follie in the sonne, our posteritie commonly foylde at the same weapon, at which we plaide rarely. And being the worlds beaten worde, what's got ouer the Diuels backe, (that's by knauerie) must be spent vnder his bellie, (that's by lechery) being awake in these knowings, why should not I oppose 'em now, and breake destinie of her custome, preuenting that by pollicie, which without it must needes be Destinie? and I haue tooke the course, I will forthwith sicken, call for my keyes, make my Will, and dispose of all, giue my sonne this blessing, that hee trust no man, keepe his hand from a queane, and a Scriuener, liue in his fathers faith, and doe good to no bodie: then will I begin to raue like a fellow of a wide conscience, and for all the worlde counterfeit to the life, that which I know I shall do when I die, take on for my golde, my landes, and my wrytings, grow worse and worse, call vpon the Diuell, and so make an ende: by this time I haue indented with a couple of searchers, who to vphold my deuice shall fray them out a'th Chamber with report of sicknesse, and so la, I start vp, and recouer agen: for in this businesse I will trust, no not my spirits Falslight & shortyard, but in disguise note the condition of al, how pittiful my wife takes my death, which wil appear by Nouember in her eye, and the fall of the leaf in her bodie, but especially by the cost she bestows vpon my funeral, there shall I trie her loue and regard, my daughters marrying to my will & lyking, and my sonnes affection after my disposing: for to conclude, I am as jealous of this land as of my wife, to know what would become of it after my decease.

div.stage: Enter Curtezan with her disguised father.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Tho I be poore, tis my glorie to liue honest.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I prethee doe not leaue me.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.l: To be bawde.
Hell has not such an office,
I thought at first your minde had beene preseru'd,
In vertue and in modestie of bloud,
that such a face had not bene made to please the vnsetled Appetites of seuerall men,
Those eyes turn'd vp through prayer, not through lust,
But you are wicked, and my thoughts vniust.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Why thou art an vnreasonable fellow yfaith, doe not al Trades liue by their ware, and yet cald honest Liuers? doe they not thriue best, when they vtter moste, and make it away by the great? is not hole-sale the chiefest marchandize? doe you thinke some Merchants could keepe their wiues so braue but for their hole-sale? you'r fowly deceiu'd and you thinke so.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: You are so glewde to punishent and shame, Your wordes ee'n deserue whipping— to beare the habit of a Gentlewoman, and be in minde so distant.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Why you foole you, are not Gentlewomen Sinners? and there's no coragious Sinner amongst vs, but was a Gentlewoman by the Mothers side I warrant you: besides, wee are not alwaies bound to thinke those our fathers that marrie our Mothers, but those that lye with our Mothers, and they may be Gentlemen borne & born agen for ought we know, you knowe.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: True: corruption may well be Generations first, Wee're bad by nature, but by custome worst.

div.stage: A Bell Toales, a Confused crie within.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Oh my Husband.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: My Father, O my Father.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: My sweete Maister, dead!

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Runne boy, bid 'em ring out, hee's dead, hee's gone.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Then is as arrant a knaue gone, as ere was cal'd vppon.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: The happyest good that euer Shortyard felt,
I want to be exprest, my mirth is such,
To bee struck now eene when his ioyes were hye,
Men onely kisse their knaueries, and so dye,
Iu'e often markt it.
Hee was a famous Coozner while he liu'd,
And now his Sonne shall reape it, ile ha the lands,
Let him Studye law after, tis no labour
to vndoe him for euer: but for Easie,
Onely good confidence did make him foolish,
And not the lack of Sence, that was not it,
Tis worldly craft beates downe a Schollars wit,
For this our Sonne and heyre now, hee
From his conception was entayl'd an Asse,
And hee ha's kept it well, twentie fiue yeares now,
Then the sleightest art will doo't, the landes lye faire,
No Sinne to begger a deceiuers heyre.

div.stage: Enter Tomazin with Winefride her maide in hast.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Heere Wenefride, heere, heere, heere, I haue alwaies found thee secret.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: You shall alwaies finde me so Mistris.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Take this letter and this Ring.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Oh how all the partes about me shake,— enquire for one Maister Easie at his olde lodging 'ith the Blackfryers,

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I will indeed forsooth.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Tell him the partie that sent him a hundred pound tother day to confort his heart, ha's likewise sent him this Letter and this Ring, which has that vertue to recouer him agen for euer say— name no body Winifride.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Not so much as you forsooth.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Good Girle, thou shalt haue a mourning Gowne at the buryall of mine honestie.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: And ile effect your will a my Fedelitie.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: I doe account my selfe the happyest Widdowe that euer counterfetted weeping, in that I haue the leasure now, both to doe that Gentleman good, and doe my selfe a pleasure, but I must seeme like a hanging Moone a little waterish a while.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.l: I entertaine both thee and thy Deuice,
Twill put e'm both to shame.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: That is my hope sir,
Especially that strumpet.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.l: Saue you sweete widdowe,
I suffer for your heauinesse.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: O Maister Rerage, I haue lost the dearest husband that euer woman did inioy.

sp.speaker: Rerg.
sp.p: You must haue patience yet.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Oh talke not to mee of patience and you loue me, good Maister Rerage.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Yet if all tongues goe right, hee did not vse you so wel as a man mought.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Nay, that's true indeed Maister Rerage, he nere vsd me so well as a woman might haue beene vsde, that's certain in troth ta's beene our greatest falling out sir, and though it be the part of a widdowe, to show her selfe a woman for her Husbands death, yet when I remember al his vnkindnesse, I cannot weepe a stroake yfaith Maister Rerage, and therefore wisely did a great widdow in this land, comfort vp another, goe too Lady (quoth she) leaue blubbering, thou thinkest vpon thy husbands good parts when thou sheddest teares, doe but remember how often hee ha's laine from thee, and how many naughtie slipperie turnes he has done thee, & thou wilt nere weepe for him I warrant thee— you would not thinke how that counsell ha's wrought with me Maister Rerage, I could not dispend another teare now, and you would giue me nere so much.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Why I count you the wiser Widdowe, it showes you haue wisdome, when you can checke your passion, for mine owne part, I haue no sence to sorrowe for his death, whose life was the onely Rub to my affection.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Troth and so it was to mine, but take courage now, your'e a Landed Gentleman, & my Daughter is seauen hundred pound strong to ioyne with you.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: But Lethe lyes 'ith way.

sp.speaker: Tomaz.
sp.p: Let him lye still, You shall treade ore him or ile faile in will.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Sweete widdowe.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p:
What a beloude man did I liue? my Seruants gall their fingers with ringing, my wiues cheeks smart with weeping,
stand in euerie corner, you may take water in my house— but am not I a wise foole now? what if my wife should take my death so to heart, that shee should sicken vppon't, nay swone, nay dye? when did I heare of a woman doe so, let mee see,— Now I remember me, I thinke twas before my Time; yes, I haue heard of those wiues that haue wept, and sobd, and swound— marry I neuer heard but they recouered agen, that's a confort la, that's a comfort, & I hope so will mine— peace, tis nere vppon the time, I see, here comes the worshipful liuerie, I haue the Hospital Boyes, I perceiue little Tomazin will bestow cost of me,— Ile listen to the common censure now, how the world tongues me when my eare lyes lowe.

sp.speaker: 1. Liue.
sp.p: Who Quomodo? meerely enricht by shifts, And cousnages, beleeue it.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: I see the world is verye loath to praise me,
Tis Rawlye friendes with me, I cannot blame it,
For what I haue done, has beene to vexe and shame it.
Heere comes my Sonne, the hope, the landed heyre,
Ont whose rare thrift, will say mens tongues you lye,
Ile keepe by lawe what was got craftily.
Me thinkes I heare him say so:
He does salute the liuerie with good grace,
And solemne Gesture—

sp.speaker: Bead.
sp.p: oh my yong Worshipful M. you haue parted from a deere Father, a wise and proui-dent father.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Art thou growne an Asse now?

sp.speaker: Bead.
sp.p: Such an honest Father—

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Prethee Beadle leaue thy lying, I am scarce able to endure thee yfaith, what honesty didst thou ere know by my Father speake, rule your tongue Beadle least I make you proue it, and then I knowe what will become of you, tis the scuruy scuruyest thing i'th earth to belye the dead so, and hee's a beastly Sonne and heyre that wil stand by, and heare his father belyed to his face, hee will nere prosper I warrant him, Troth if I be not asham'd to goe to Church with him, I would I might be hang'd, I feare such filthye Tales goe on him, oh
if I had knowne hee had beene such a lewde fellow in his life hee should nere haue kept me company.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Oh— o— o!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: But I am glad hee's gone, tho twere long first, Shortyard and I will reuell it yfaith, I haue made him my Rentgatherer alreadie.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Hee shall bee speedilye disinherited, hee gettes not a foote, not the Crowne of a Mole-hill, ile sooner make a courtyer my heyre for teaching my wife trickes then thee, my moste neglectfull Sonne? Oh now the coarse, I shall obserue yet farder.

div.stage: A counterfet Coarse brought in, Tomazin, and al the mourners equally counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O my moste modest, vertuous and remembring wife, she shall haue all when I dye, she shall haue all.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Maister Easie? tis, oh what shift shall I make now? oh—

div.stage: Falls downe in a fayned swound.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Sweete wife she sownes, ile let her alone, ile haue no mercie at this time, ile not see her, ile follow the coarse.

sp.speaker: Eas:
sp.p: The Deuill grinde thy Bones, thou cousning Rascal.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Giue her a little more ayre, tilt vp her head, comfort thy selfe good widdowe, doe not fall like a Beast for a husband, there's more then wee can well tell where to put e'm, good soule.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Oh, I shall be well anon.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Fye, you haue no patience yfaith, I haue buried foure Husbands, and neuer offered e'm such abuse.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Couzen, how doe you?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Sorry to see you ill Couze.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: The worst is past I hope.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I hope so to.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Lend me your hand sweet Couze I haue troubled you

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: No trouble indeed forsooth— Good Couzen haue a care of her, comfort her vp as much as you can, and all little ynough I warrant yee.

sp.speaker: Tomaz.
sp.p: My moste sweete loue.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: My life is not so deere.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: I haue alwaies pittyed you.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Y'aue showne it heere. And giuen the desperate hope?

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Delay not now, y'aue vnderstood my loue, I haue a priest readye, this is the fittest season, no eye offends vs, Let this kisse Restore thee to more wealth, me to more blisse.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: The Angels haue prouided for me.

div.head: Incipit Quintus et Vltimus.
div.stage: Enter Shortyard with writings, hauing cousned Sim Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I haue not Scope ynough within my brest,
To keepe my ioyes containde: I'me Quomodoes
heire: the Lands assurances, and all are mine
(I haue tript his Sonnes heeles vp) aboue the ground,
His father left him: had I not encouragement?
Do not I knowe what proues the Fathers pray?
The Sonne nere lookes on't, but it melts away.
Doe not I knowe the wealth that's got by fraude?
Slaue's share it like the ritches of a Bawde.
Why tis a curse vnquenchable, nere cooles.
Knaues still commit their consciences to fooles:
And they betray who o'wde em, heeres all the bonds,
All Easies writings, let me see:

div.stage: Enter Quomodoes Wife marryed to Easie.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Now my desires weare crownes.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: My ioyes exceede, Man is neere healthfull, till his follyes bleede.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Oh, beholde the Villaine, who in all those shapes Confounded your estate.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: That slaue, that villaine.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: So many Acres of good meadowe—

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Rascall.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I heare you sir.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Rogue, Shortyard, Blastfield, Serjeant, Deputy, cousner

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Holde, holde.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I thirst the execution of his eares.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Hate you that office,

sp.speaker: Easi.
sp.p: Ile strip him bare for punishment and shame.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why doe but heare me sir, you will not thinke what I haue done for you.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Giuen his Sonne my Lands.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Why looke you, tis not so, your not tolde true,
I haue Coosned him agen meerely for you,
Meerely for you sir, twas my meaning then
That you should wed her, and haue all agen.
sp.p: A my troth 'its true sir: looke you then heere sir, you shall not misse a little scrowle sir, pray sir, let not the Cittie knowe me for a knaue, there be ritcher men would enuie my preferment if I should be knowne before e'm.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.l: Villaine, my hate to more reuenge is drawne,
When slaues are found, tis their base Arte to fawne,
Within there—.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How now? fresh warders.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: This is the other, binde him fast, haue I found you Maister Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: This is the fruite of Craft,
Like him that shootes vp hye, lookes for the shaft
And findes it in his fore-head, so does hit
The Arrowe of our fate, wit destroyes wit:
The head the bodyes bane, and his owne beares,
You hae Corne enough, you neede not reape mine eares,
Sweete Maister Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I loath his voice, away.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: What happynesse was heere, but are you sure you haue all?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I hope so my sweete wife.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What difference there is in Husbands, not onelye in one thing, but in all.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Heeres good deedes and bad deedes, the writings that keep my lands to me, and the bonds that gaue it away from me.
sp.l: These my good deedes shall to more safetie turne,
And these my bad haue their desarts and burne.
Ile see thee agen presently, reade there.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Did he want all, who would not loue his care?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What a wife hast thou Ephestian— Quomodo, so louing so mindefull of her duetye not onely seene to weep but knowne to swone, I knew a Widdow about Saint Antlings so forgetfull of hir first Husband, that she marryed agen within the tweluemonth, nay some berladye within the month: there were sights to be seen, had they my wiues true sorrows seauen nor seauen yeares would drawe e'm to the stake, I would moste tradesmen had such a wife as I, they hope they haue, wee must all hope the best: thus in her honour.

div.l: A modest wife is such a Iewell,
He that's honest, and not cruell,
Is the likelyest man to owe it.
div.p: And that's I, I made it by my selfe, and comming to her as a Beadle for my reward this morning, ile see how shee takes my death next her heart.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Now Beadle.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Blesse your mistrisships eyes from too many teares, Although you haue lost a wise and worshipfull Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: You come for your due Beadle, heere 'ith house.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Most certaine, the Hospitall money and mine owne poore forty pence.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: I must craue a discharge from you Beadle.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Call your man, ile heartilye see my hand to a Memorandum.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: You deale the truel yer.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Good wench still.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: George, heere is the Beadle come for his money, draw a Memorandum that he has receiued all his due he can claim heere ith house after this funerall.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p:
What politick directions shee giues him, all to secure her selfe, tis time yfaith now to pitty her, ile discouer my selfe to her ere I goe, but came it off with some liuely iest now, that were admyrable: I haue it? after the memorandum is written and all, ile set my owne name too't Ephestian Quomodo,
sheele start, sheele wonder how Ephest. Quomodo came hither that was buried yesterday: y'are beset little Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ninteene, twentie fiue pound, 1, 2, 3, & 4. d.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: So, we shall haue good sport, when tis read:

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: How now Ladie, paying away money so fast?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: The Beadles due here sir

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Whose? tis Easie, what makes Easie in my house, Hee is not my wiues ouer seer I hope:

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Whats here?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He makes me sweate.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Memorandum that I haue receiued of Richard Easie, all my due I can claime here i'th house or any hereafter for me: In witnesse whereof, I haue set to mine owne hand, Ephestian Qommodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What haue I done? was I mad?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Ephestian Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I, well, what then sir? get you out of my house, First you maister Prodigall had land, away.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What is the Beadle drunke or mad? Where are my men to thrust him out a doores.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Not so good Tomazin not so.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: This fellow must be whipt.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Thanke you good wife.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I can no longer beare him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay sweete husband.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Husband I me vndone, beggard, couzend, confounded for euer: married alreadie? will it please you knowe mee now mistris Harlot, and master Horner, who am I now?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Oh, hee's as like my tother husband as can be.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Ile haue iudgement, ile bring you before a Iudge, you shall feele wife whether my flesh be dead or no, ile tickle you yfaith, yfaith.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: The Iudge that heele solicite knowes me well.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Lets on then, and our greeuances first tell.

div.stage: Enter Lethe with officers, taken with his Harlot.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Here they come.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: O where.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Hart of shame, vpon my wedding morning so disgracd!
Haue you so little conscience Officers,
You will not take a bribe?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Master Lethe we may lie together lawfully hereafter, for we are coupled together before people ynow yfaith.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: There goes the strumpet.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Pardon my wilfull blindnesse and enioy me.
For now the difference appeares too plaine,
Betwixt a base slaue and a true Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.l: I doe embrace thee in the best of loue,
How soone affections fail, how soone they proue.

div.stage: Enter Iudge, Easie, and Tomazin in talke with him.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: His cousnages are odious, he the plaintife,
Not onely framde deceitfull in his life,
But so to mocke his funerall.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.l: Most iust.
The Liuerie all assembled, mourning weedes,
Throughout his house een down to his last seruant
The Herauld richly hirde to lend him Armes,
Faind from his Auncestors, which I dare sweare knewe no
other Armes but those they labour'd with,
All preparations furnisht, nothing wanted
Saue that which was the cause of all, his death,
If he be liuing.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.p: Twas an impious part.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.l: We are not certaine yet it is himselfe,
But some false spirit that assumes his shape,
And seekes still to deceiue mee.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Oh are you come? my Lord? their here, good morrow Tomazin.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.p: Now what are you?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: I am Quomodo my Lord, & this my wife,
Those my two men, that are bound wrongfully.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: How are we sure y'are he?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Oh you cannot misse my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: Ile trie you. Are you the man that liu'd the famous cousner?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O no my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Did you deceiue this Gentleman of his right,
And laid Nets ore his land?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Not I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Then y'are not Quomodo but a counterfet,
Lay hands on him, and beare him to the whip.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Stay, stay a little I pray, now I remember me my Lord, I cousned him indeed, tis wondrous true.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Then I dare sweare this is no counterfet.
Let all doubts cease this man is Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why la you now, you would not beleeue this, I am found what I am.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: But setting these thy odious shifts apart,
Why did that thought prophane, enter thy brest,
To mocke the world with thy supposed death?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Conceiue you not that my Lord? a policy.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: For hauing gotten the lands I thirsted still,
To know what fate would follow 'em.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: Being ill got.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Your Lorpship apprehends me.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: I thinke I shall anon.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: And thereupon,
I out of policie possest my sonne,
Which since I haue found lewd, and now intend
To disinherit him for euer,
Not onely this was in my death set downe,
But thereby a firme triall of my wife,
Her constant sorrowes, her remembring vertues,
All which are Dewes, the shine of a next morning dries 'em vp all I see't.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Did you professe wise cousenage, and would dare
To put a woman to her two dayes choice,
When of a minute do's it?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: Lesse, a moment
The twinckling of an eye, a glimpse, scarce somthing do's it,
Your Lordship yet will graunt she is my wife.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: O heauen!

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: After some penance, and the Deues of law
I must acknowledge that.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: I scarce like
Those Deues of lawe.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.l: My Lord, altho the law too gently lot his wife,
The wealth he left behind he cannot chalenge.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Behold his hand against it.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He do's deuize all meanes to make mee mad, that I may no more lie with my wife in perfect memorie, I know't but yet the landes will maintaine me in my wits: the lande will doe so much for mee.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.l: In witnesse whereof I haue set to mine owne hand,
Ephestian Quomodo.
Tis firme enough your owne sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: A iest my Lord, I did I knew not what.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: It should seeme so, deceit is her owne foe
Craftily gets, and childishly lets goe.
But yet the lands are his.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I, warrant yee.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: No my good Lord, the lands know the right heire, I am their master once more.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Haue you the lands?

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: Yes truly I praise heauen.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Is this good dealing? are there such consciences abroad, how? which way could he come by 'em?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: My Lord ile quickly resolue you that it comes to me
This cousner whom too long I call'd my patrone,
To my thought dying, and the foole his sonne
Possest of all, which my braine partly sweat for,
I held it my best vertue, by a plot
To get from him what for him was ill got.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O beastly Shortyard!

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: When no sooner mine,
But I was glad more quickly to resigne.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: Craft once discouer'd shewes her abiect line.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: He hits me euery where, for craft once knowne,
Do's teach fooles wit, leaues the deceiuer none.
My deedes haue cleft me, cleft me.

div.stage: Enter Officers with Lethe and the Harlot.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Roome there.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: A little yet to raise my spirit.
Here maister Lethe comes to wed my Daughter.
That's all the ioy is left me: ha? who's this?

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.p: What crimes haue those brought foorth?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: The shame of lust,
Most viciously on this his wedding morning,
This man was ceazde in shame with that bolde Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.p: Why, tis she he meanes to marrye.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: No in truth.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.l: In truth you doe.
Who for his wife his Harlot doth preferre,
Good reason tis, that he should marrie her.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I craue it on my knees, such was his vowe at first,

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Ile say so too
And worke out mine owne safetie,
Such was his vowe at first, indeede my Lord,
How ere his moode has chang'd him?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: O vilde slaue!

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: He sayes it true my Lord,

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Rest content,
He shall both marrie and taste punishment.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Oh intollerable! I beseech your good Lordship if I must haue an outward punishment, let me not marrie an inward, whose lastes will nere out, but growe worse and worse: I haue a wife staies for me this morning with seauen hundred pound in her pursse, let me be speedily whipt and be gone, I beseech your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Hee speakes no truth my Lord, behold the Virgin,
Wife to a well esteemed Gentleman,
Loathing the Sin he followes.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: I was betrayed, yes faith.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.l: His owne Mother my Lord,
Which hee confest through ignorance, and disdaine,
His name so chang'd to abuse the world and her.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p:
Marry a Harlot, why not? tis an honest mans fortune,
I pray did not one of my Countriemen marrye my Sister? why well then, if none should be marryed but those that are honest where should a man seeke a wife after Christmas? I pitty that Gentleman, that has nine Daughters to bestowe, and seauen of e'm Seeded already, they wil be good stuffe by that time, I doe beseech your Lordship to remoue the punishment, I am content to marrie her.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.p: There's no remouing of your punishment.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: O good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.l: Vnlesse one heere assembled
Whom you haue most vnnaturally abusde, beget your pardon.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.l: Who should that be?
Or who would doote, that has beene so abusde?
A troublesome pennance— sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Knaue in your face, leaue your mocking, Andrew, marrie your Qeane and be quiet.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Maister Easie.

sp.speaker: Eas.
sp.p: I'me sorrie you take such a bad course sir.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Maister Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Enquire my right name agen next time, now goe your waies like an Asse as you came.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Masse I forget my mother all this while, Ile make her doo't at first, pray mother your blessing for once.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Calst me Mother? out, I defie thee slaue.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Call me slaue as much as you will, but doe not shame me now, let the world knowe you are my Mother.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Let me not haue this Villaine put vpon me I beseech your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.l: Hee's iustly curst, she loathes to know him now,
Whome he before did as much loath to knowe,
Wilt thou beleeue me woman?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: That's soone done.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.p: Then knowe him for a Villaine, tis thy Sonne,

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Art thou Andrew my wicked Sonne Andrew?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: You would not beleeue me Mother.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
How art thou chang'd? Is this sute fit for thee? a Tooth-drawers Sonne,
this countrie has ee'ne spoilde thee since thou camst heather, thy manners better then thy cloathes, but now whole cloathes and ragged manners, it may well be saide that truth goes naked, for when thou hadst scarce a shirt thou hadst more truth about thee.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.l: Thou art thine owne affliction Quomodo:
Shortyard we banish, tis our pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Hence foorth no woman shall complaine for measure.

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.l: And that all Error from our workes may stand,
We bannish Falslight euermore the land.
